chunks.original_text: 缵义德胜者霸得人心也胜敌者强得人力也然非得人之心未有能用人之力也敌何由胜强何由霸哉德自得也自得则柔弱胜刚强故能胜不若已者至于若于己者而格是德相若也柔胜出于若已者其事不可度则德又胜我矣故能以众不胜成大胜者惟圣人能之 文子缵义卷四 钦定四库全书 文子缵义卷五　　　　　宋　杜道坚　撰 道德篇 文子问道老子曰学问不精听道不深凡听者将以达智也 将以成行也 将以致功名也 不精不明不深不达故上学以神听中学以心听下学以耳 听以耳 听者学在皮肤以心听者学在肌肉以神听者学在骨髓故听之不深即知之不明知之不明即不能尽其精不能尽其精即行之不成凡听之理虚心清静损气无盛无思无虑目无妄视耳 无苟听专精积蓄内意盈并既以得之必固守之必长久之夫道者原产有始始于柔弱成于刚强始于短寡成于众长十围之木始于把百仞之台始于下此天之道也 圣人法之卑者所以自下也 退者所以自后也 俭者所以自小也 损者所以自少也 卑则尊退则先俭则广损则大此天道所成也 夫道者德之元天之根福之门万物待之而生待之而成待之而宁夫道无为无形内以修身外以治人功成事立与天为邻无为而无不为莫知其情莫知其真其中有信天子有道则天下服长有社稷公侯有道则人民和睦不失其国士庶有道则全其身保其亲强大有道不战而克小弱有道不争而得举事有道功成得福君臣有道则忠惠父子有道则慈孝士庶有道则相爱故有道则和无道则苛由是观之道之于人无所不宜也 夫道者小行之小得福大行之大得福尽行之天下服服则懐之故帝者天下之适也 王者天下之往也 天下不适不往不可谓帝王故帝王不得人不能成得人失道亦不能守夫失道者奢泰骄佚慢倨矜傲见余自显自明执雄坚强作难结怨为兵主为乱首小人行之身受大殃大人行之国家灭亡浅及其身深及子孙夫罪莫大于无道怨莫深于无德天道然也 老子曰夫行道者使人虽勇刺之不入虽巧击之不中夫刺之不入击之不中而犹辱也未若使人虽勇不敢刺虽巧不敢击夫不敢者非无其意也未若使人无其意夫无其意者未有爱利之心也不若使天下丈夫女子莫不欢然皆欲爱利之若然者无地而为君无官而为长天下莫不愿安利之故勇于敢则杀勇于不敢则活 文子问德老子曰畜之养之遂之长之兼利无择与天地合此之谓德何谓仁曰为上不矜其功为下不羞其病于大不矜于小不偷兼爱无私久而不衰此之谓仁也 何谓义曰为上则辅弱为下则守节达不肆意穷不易操一度顺理不私枉挠此之谓义也 何谓礼曰为上则恭严为下则卑敬退让守柔为天下雌立于不敢设于不能此之谓礼也 故修其德则下从令修其仁则下不争修其义则下平正修其礼则下尊敬四者既修国家安宁故物生者道也 长者德也 爱者仁也 正者义也 敬者礼也 不畜不养不能遂长不慈不爱不能成遂不正不匡不能久长不敬不宠不能贵重故德者民之所贵也 仁者民之所懐也 义者民之所畏也 礼者民之所敬也 此四者文之顺也 圣人之所以御万物也 君子无德则下怨无仁则下争无义则下暴无礼则下乱四经不立谓之无道无道不亡者未之有也 老子曰至德之世贾便其市农乐其野大夫安其职处士修其道人民乐其业是以风雨不毁折草木不天死河出图洛出书及世之衰也赋敛无度杀戮无止刑谏者杀贤士是以山崩川涸蠕动不息野无百蔬故世治则愚者不得独乱世乱则贤者不能独治圣人和愉宁静生也至德道行命也故生遭命而后能行命得时而后能明必有其世而后有其人
chunks.translated_text:
He who inherits the meaning of virtue prevails as a hegemon by winning the hearts of others; he who prevails over enemies is strong by employing the strength of others. Yet without winning the hearts of others, none can employ their strength. How then can enemies be overcome? How can strength lead to hegemony? Virtue arises from self-attainment. Self-attainment yields yielding and weakness, which prevail over rigidity and strength. Thus, one can prevail over those not equal to oneself. When it comes to those equal to oneself, this is a case of equal virtue. Yet yielding surpasses those equal to oneself—its outcome cannot be fathomed. Here, virtue again prevails over oneself. Therefore, to achieve great victory with those who cannot prevail—only the sage can do this.

*Wenzi, Inheriting the Meaning, Scroll 4*
*Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries, Wenzi, Inheriting the Meaning, Scroll 5*
*By Du Daojian of the Song Dynasty*

**The Dao and Virtue**

Wenzi asked Dao of Laozi, saying: "When learning is not refined and listening to the Dao is not profound, how can one who listens hope to attain wisdom, perfect conduct, or achieve merit and fame? Without refinement, there is no clarity; without depth, there is no attainment. Thus, in superior learning, one listens with spirit; in middling learning, one listens with the heart; in inferior learning, one listens with the ears. To listen with the ears is to have learning in the skin; to listen with the heart is to have learning in the flesh; to listen with spirit is to have learning in the bone marrow. If listening is not profound, knowledge is not clear; if knowledge is not clear, one cannot exhaust its essence; if one cannot exhaust its essence, conduct cannot be perfected.

In general, the principle of listening requires an empty mind, tranquility, and the reduction of qi—without excess, without thought, without worry. The eyes must not gaze recklessly, nor the ears listen carelessly. One must concentrate, accumulate, and store within, filling the intent and merging it. Once attained, one must firmly guard it and preserve it for long.

The Dao is the origin and source of all things, the beginning of all beginnings. It begins in softness and weakness, and is completed in hardness and strength. It begins in brevity and scarcity, and is completed in abundance and length. A tree ten spans in girth begins as a handful; a terrace of a hundred fathoms begins from below. This is the Way of Heaven. The sage models himself upon it: humility is how one places oneself below; withdrawal is how one places oneself behind; frugality is how one makes oneself small; reduction is how one makes oneself few. Thus, humility leads to honor, withdrawal to precedence, frugality to expansiveness, and reduction to greatness—this is what the Way of Heaven accomplishes.

The Dao is the origin of virtue, the root of Heaven, the gate of fortune. All things depend on it to live, to be completed, and to find peace. The Dao is non-action and formless. Internally, it cultivates the self; externally, it governs others. When its work is accomplished and affairs are established, it neighbors Heaven. It is non-action, yet nothing is left undone. None know its true nature, none know its reality, yet within it there is sincerity.

When the Son of Heaven possesses the Dao, all under Heaven submit, and the altars of soil and grain endure. When the feudal lords possess the Dao, the people are harmonious and do not lose their states. When the scholar-commoners possess the Dao, they preserve their persons and protect their kin. When the strong and great possess the Dao, they conquer without battle. When the small and weak possess the Dao, they obtain without contention. When affairs are undertaken with the Dao, success is achieved and fortune is gained. When ruler and minister possess the Dao, there is loyalty and kindness. When father and son possess the Dao, there is affection and filial piety. When scholar-commoners possess the Dao, there is mutual love. Thus, with the Dao there is harmony; without it, there is harshness. From this, it is evident that the Dao is fitting for all people in all circumstances.

The Dao, when practiced in small matters, brings small fortune; when practiced in great matters, brings great fortune. When practiced to its fullest, all under Heaven submit. Submission leads to cherishing. Thus, the emperor is the one to whom all under Heaven turn; the king is the one to whom all under Heaven go. If all under Heaven do not turn or go, one cannot be called emperor or king. Therefore, even if an emperor or king gains the people, without the Dao he cannot succeed; even if he gains the people but loses the Dao, he cannot preserve his position.

Those who lose the Dao are extravagant, arrogant, indolent, and lazy. They are haughty, self-important, and self-aggrandizing. They hold to dominance and rigidity, create difficulties, sow enmity, provoke warfare, and become the instigators of chaos. When petty men practice this, they bring great calamity upon themselves; when great men practice it, their states perish. The calamity may be shallow, affecting only themselves, or deep, extending to their descendants. No crime is greater than lacking the Dao; no resentment is deeper than lacking virtue. This is the Way of Heaven."

Laozi said: "One who practices the Dao causes others, though brave, to be unable to pierce him, and though skillful, to be unable to strike him. Though they cannot pierce or strike him, he is still humiliated—this is not as good as causing others, though brave, to dare not pierce him, and though skillful, to dare not strike him. Yet even this 'daring not' is not the absence of intent—it is not as good as causing others to have no such intent. When there is no such intent, there is no mind of love or benefit—it is not as good as causing all men and women under Heaven to rejoice and desire to love and benefit him. When this is so, there is no land where one is not a ruler, no office where one is not a leader. All under Heaven wish for his peace and benefit. Thus, courage in daring leads to death; courage in not daring leads to life."

Wenzi asked about virtue. Laozi said: "To nurture, nourish, foster, and grow; to benefit all without partiality; to unite with Heaven and Earth—this is called virtue. What is benevolence? To be above without boasting of merit, to be below without shame of faults; in great matters not to be arrogant, in small matters not to be negligent; to love universally without selfishness, and to endure without decline—this is called benevolence. What is righteousness? To be above and assist the weak, to be below and uphold integrity; when prosperous, not to indulge one’s desires; when impoverished, not to change one’s principles; to measure by the standard, follow principle, and not act selfishly or perversely—this is called righteousness. What is propriety? To be above and be reverent and solemn, to be below and be humble and respectful; to yield and be the female of all under Heaven; to stand in not daring, to establish in inability—this is called propriety.

Thus, cultivating virtue causes those below to follow commands; cultivating benevolence causes those below not to contend; cultivating righteousness causes those below to be upright; cultivating propriety causes those below to be respectful. When these four are cultivated, the state is peaceful and secure. Therefore, the Dao gives birth to things; virtue nurtures them; benevolence loves them; righteousness rectifies them; propriety respects them. Without nurturing and nourishing, one cannot foster growth; without kindness and love, one cannot bring to completion; without rectitude and correction, one cannot endure; without respect and honor, one cannot esteem and value. Thus, virtue is what the people cherish; benevolence is what the people embrace; righteousness is what the people fear; propriety is what the people respect. These four are the proper sequence of culture and the means by which the sage governs the myriad things.

When the noble man lacks virtue, those below resent him; without benevolence, those below contend; without righteousness, those below are violent; without propriety, those below are chaotic. When these four classics are not established, it is called lacking the Dao. There has never been one who lacked the Dao and did not perish."

Laozi said: "In the age of utmost virtue, merchants find convenience in the marketplace, farmers delight in the fields, great officers are secure in their posts, recluses cultivate their ways, and the people enjoy their occupations. Thus, wind and rain do not destroy, plants and trees do not die prematurely, the Yellow River yields its diagrams, and the Luo River yields its writings. When the age declines, taxes and levies are without measure, killing and execution are unceasing, those who remonstrate with punishments are killed, and worthy scholars are suppressed. Thus, mountains collapse, rivers dry up, creeping things do not rest, and the wilds lack all vegetation.

Therefore, when the world is well-governed, even fools cannot alone cause disorder; when the world is in chaos, even the worthy cannot alone bring order. The sage is harmonious, joyful, and tranquil in life. When the utmost virtue and the Dao prevail, it is fate. Thus, life encounters fate and then can act; fate meets the times and then can be understood. There must be the right age before there can be the right person."

chunks.original_text: 文子问圣智老子曰闻而知之圣也见而知之智也故圣人常闻祸福所生而择其道智者常见祸福成形而择其行圣人知天道吉凶故知祸福所生智者先见成形故知祸福之门闻未生圣也先见成形智也无闻见者愚迷 老子曰君好义则信时而任己弃数而用惠物博智浅以浅赡博未之有也 独任其智失必多矣 好智穷术也 好勇危亡之道也 好与则无定分上之分不定则下之望无止若多敛则与民为雠少取而多与其数无有故好与来怨之道也 由是观之财不足任道术可因明矣 文子问曰古之王者以道莅天下为之奈何老子曰执一无为因天地与之变化天下大器也 不可执也 不可为也 为者败之执者失之执者见小也 见小故不能成其大也 无为者守静也 守静能为天下正处大满而不溢居高贵而无骄处大不溢盈而不亏居上不骄高而不危盈而不亏所以长守富也 高而不危所以长守贵也 富贵不离其身禄及子孙古之王道具于此矣 老子曰民有道所同行有法所同守义不能相固威不能相必故立君以一之君执一即治无常即乱君道者非所以有为也 所以无为也 智者不以德为事勇者不以力为暴仁者不以位为惠可谓一矣 一也 者无适之道也 万物之本也 君数易法国数易君人以其位达其好憎下之任惧不可胜理故君失一其乱甚于无君也 君必执一而后能群矣 文子问曰王道有几老子曰一而已矣 文子曰古有以道王者有以兵王者何其一也曰以道王者德也以兵王者亦德也用兵者五有义兵有应兵有忿兵有贪兵有骄兵诛暴救弱谓之义敌来加已不得已而用之谓之应争小故不胜其心谓之忿利人土地欲人财货谓之贪恃其国家之大矜其人民之众欲见贤于敌国者谓之骄义兵王应兵胜忿兵败贪兵死骄兵灭此天道也 老子曰释道而任智者危弃数而用才者困故守分循理失之不忧得之不喜成者非所为得者非所求入者有受而无取出者有授而无与因春而生因秋而杀所生不德所杀不怨则几于道矣 文子问曰王者得其欢心为之奈何老子曰若江海即是也淡兮无味用之不既先小而后大夫欲上人者必以其言下之欲先人者必以其身后之天下必效其欢爱进其仁义而无苛气居上而民不重居前而众不害天下乐推而不厌虽绝国殊俗蜎飞蠕动莫不亲爱无之而不通无往而不遂故为天下贵 老子曰执一世之法籍以非传代之俗譬犹胶柱调瑟圣人者应时权变见形施宜世异则事变时移则俗易论世立法随时举事上古之王法度不同非古相返也时务异也是故不法其已成之法而法其所以为法者与化推移圣人之法可观也其所以作法不可原也其言可听也其所以言不可形也三皇五帝轻天下细万物齐死生同变化抱道推诚以镜万物之情上与道为友下与化为人今欲学其道不得其清明圣守其法籍行其宪令必不能以为治矣 文子问政老子曰御之以道养之以德无示以贤无加以力损而执一无处可利无见可欲方而不割廉而不刿无矜无伐御之以道则民附养之以德则民服无示以贤则民足无加以力则民朴无示以贤者俭也无加以力不敢也下以聚之赂以取之俭以自全不敢以自安不下则离散弗养则背叛示以贤则民争加以力则民怨离散则国势衰民背叛则上无威人争则轻为非下怨其上则位危四者诚修正道几矣 老子曰上言者下用也下言者上用也上言者常用也下言者权用也唯圣人为能知权言而必信期而必当天下之高行直而证父信而死女孰能贵之故圣人论事之曲直与之屈伸无常仪表祝则名君溺则捽父势使然也夫权者圣人所以独见夫先迕而后合者之谓权先合而后迕者不知权不知权者善反丑矣
chunks.translated_text:
Wenzi asked about sagacity and wisdom. Laozi said: "To know by hearing is sagacity; to know by seeing is wisdom. Thus, the sage constantly perceives where fortune and misfortune arise and chooses the Way accordingly. The wise constantly see fortune and misfortune take shape and choose their conduct accordingly. The sage knows the auspicious and inauspicious of Heaven’s Dao, thus knowing where fortune and misfortune arise. The wise foresee their formation, thus knowing the gateway of fortune and misfortune. To hear before they arise is sagacity; to see before they form is wisdom. Those without hearing or seeing are foolish and deluded."

Laozi said: "If a ruler favors righteousness, he will trust the times and rely on himself, abandoning calculation to employ kindness. Broad knowledge with shallow means cannot deeply provide; broadness without depth has never existed. Relying solely on one’s wisdom, failures will be many. Favoring wisdom is the path to exhausted strategies; favoring courage is the path to peril and ruin. Favoring bestowal leads to no fixed share—if the ruler’s portion is not fixed, the people’s expectations will be endless. If heavy exactions are made, it turns the people into enemies. Taking little but giving much, such calculations will cease. Thus, favoring bestowal is the path that invites resentment. From this, it is clear: wealth is insufficient to employ the Dao and its arts; one must rely on clarity."

Wenzi asked: "How did the kings of antiquity govern the world with the Dao?" Laozi said: "They held to the One and practiced non-action, following Heaven and Earth and adapting to their transformations. The world is a great vessel—it cannot be grasped or acted upon. To act is to ruin it; to grasp is to lose it. Those who grasp see only the small; seeing the small, they cannot accomplish the great. Non-action means maintaining stillness. By maintaining stillness, one can rectify the world. Abiding in great fullness without overflowing, dwelling in high nobility without arrogance—abiding in greatness without overflowing, full yet not deficient; dwelling above without arrogance, exalted yet not imperiled; full yet not deficient, thus long preserving wealth; exalted yet not imperiled, thus long preserving nobility. Wealth and nobility do not depart from one’s person, and blessings extend to descendants. The kingly Dao of antiquity was complete in this."

Laozi said: "The people have a Dao they all follow, laws they all uphold. Righteousness cannot firmly bind them, nor can might compel them. Thus, a ruler is established to unify them. When the ruler holds to the One, there is order; without constancy, there is chaos. The ruler’s Dao is not for action but for non-action. The wise do not make virtue their task; the brave do not employ force for violence; the benevolent do not use position for favor—this is called unity. Unity is the Dao without preference, the root of the myriad things. If a ruler frequently changes the state’s laws, and the state frequently changes its ruler, people use their positions to pursue their likes and dislikes, and the tasks of subordinates become unmanageable. Thus, if a ruler loses the One, the chaos is worse than having no ruler. The ruler must hold to the One before he can unite the many."

Wenzi asked: "How many are the kingly ways?" Laozi said: "Only one." Wenzi said: "In antiquity, some ruled with the Dao, others with military force—how are they one?" Laozi said: "Those who rule with the Dao do so through virtue; those who rule with military force also do so through virtue. In the use of arms, there are five types: righteous armies, responsive armies, resentful armies, greedy armies, and arrogant armies. Punishing the violent and aiding the weak is called righteous; when an enemy attacks and one has no choice but to use force, it is called responsive; contending over small matters without restraining one’s heart is called resentful; desiring others’ lands and coveting their wealth is called greedy; relying on one’s state’s greatness, boasting of its people’s multitude, and seeking superiority over enemy states is called arrogant. Righteous armies triumph; responsive armies prevail; resentful armies are defeated; greedy armies perish; arrogant armies are destroyed—this is the Dao of Heaven."

Laozi said: "Abandoning the Dao to rely on wisdom leads to peril; discarding calculation to employ talent leads to distress. Thus, maintaining one’s role and following principle, one does not grieve over losses nor rejoice over gains. Success is not sought; what is obtained is not pursued. Incoming, there is reception without taking; outgoing, there is bestowal without giving. Following spring to give life, following autumn to bring death—those who live owe no gratitude; those who die bear no resentment. This is near to the Dao."

Wenzi asked: "How does a ruler gain the people’s joyful hearts?" Laozi said: "Be like the rivers and seas—bland and without flavor, inexhaustible in use. Putting the small before the great, if one wishes to lead others, one must humble one’s words before them; if one wishes to precede others, one must place oneself behind them. The world must emulate one’s joy and love, advancing one’s benevolence and righteousness without harshness. Dwelling above, the people do not find one burdensome; standing before them, the multitude is not harmed. The world delights in advancing one without weariness. Though distant lands and foreign customs, even the flying insects and creeping things, none are not cherished and loved. There is nowhere one does not reach, no place one does not succeed. Thus, one is honored by the world."

Laozi said: "Holding to the world’s laws and records to oppose the customs of succeeding generations is like gluing the pegs of a zither. The sage responds to the times with flexible adaptation, applying measures suited to circumstances. As eras differ, affairs change; as times shift, customs transform. Thus, one does not model after already established laws but models after the principles that create laws, moving with transformation. The sage’s laws can be observed, but the reasons for their creation cannot be traced; his words can be heard, but the sources of his speech cannot be discerned. The Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors held the world lightly, considered the myriad things insignificant, equated life and death, and harmonized with change. Embracing the Dao and extending sincerity, they mirrored the feelings of the myriad things. Above, they befriended the Dao; below, they accompanied transformation. Now, if one wishes to learn their Dao but does not attain their clarity and mysterious sagacity, merely adhering to their laws and records and enforcing their statutes and decrees, one certainly cannot govern effectively."

Wenzi asked about governance. Laozi said: "Guide them with the Dao, nourish them with virtue. Do not display worthiness, do not impose force. Diminish and hold to the One. Have no place for profit, no display of desire. Be square without cutting, be sharp without wounding. Be without pride, without boasting. Guide them with the Dao, and the people will attach themselves; nourish them with virtue, and the people will submit. Do not display worthiness, and the people will be content; do not impose force, and the people will be simple. Not displaying worthiness is frugality; not imposing force is humility. Descend to gather them, bestow to obtain them, be frugal to preserve oneself, be humble to secure oneself. Without descending, they scatter; without nourishing, they rebel. Displaying worthiness causes the people to contend; imposing force causes them to resent. Scattering weakens the state’s power; rebellion strips the ruler of authority. Contention leads to disregard for wrongdoing; resentment of superiors endangers one’s position. If these four are truly cultivated, the correct Dao is near."

Laozi said: "The superior’s words are employed by the inferior; the inferior’s words are employed by the superior. The superior’s words are constantly used; the inferior’s words are used flexibly. Only the sage can know the flexible words and yet be certain, fulfill expectations and yet be appropriate. The highest conduct in the world is to testify for one’s father with integrity, for one’s daughter to die for trust—who can esteem such? Thus, the sage discusses the right and wrong of affairs, bending and extending with them without fixed standards. When blessed, he is a named lord; when drowned, he is seized by his father—circumstances compel this. Flexibility is how the sage uniquely foresees. To first oppose and then conform is called flexibility; to first conform and then oppose is to not know flexibility. Those who do not know flexibility turn good into ugliness."

Wenzi asked, "Master, in your teaching, none but the Dao and virtue can govern the world. Yet among the kings of antiquity who inherited their thrones and continued their legacies, some were without the Dao—how did they pass their eras without calamity or ruin?"

Laozi replied, "From the Son of Heaven down to the common people, each sustains their own life, yet the sustenance varies in abundance. The world often sees states perish and families break apart, not for lack of the Dao and virtue. With the Dao and virtue, one rises early and retires late, ever vigilant, trembling with fear of peril. Without the Dao and virtue, one indulges desires and grows indolent—ruin comes without warning. Had Jie and Zhou followed the Dao and practiced virtue, even the worthy Tang and Wu could have achieved no merit.

The Dao and virtue are what nurture life, what rear and sustain, what foster love and affection, what command respect and esteem. Even the deaf and mute, though foolish, do not harm what they love. If all under heaven held a heart of benevolence and love, how could disaster or misfortune arise?

Those without the Dao yet free from harm still retain some thread of benevolence, some remnant of righteousness. But when benevolence is not wholly severed and righteousness not entirely lost, the feudal lords grow contemptuous of their superiors. When lords scorn their superiors, the court becomes irreverent. Should they then defy orders and disobey, when benevolence is severed and righteousness lost, lords rebel, the strong oppress the weak, the great encroach upon the small, and the people take assault as their trade. Disasters arise, chaos erupts—ruin comes swiftly. How could one expect to escape harm?

Laozi said, "When laws are excessive and punishments severe, the people grow deceitful. When the ruler is meddlesome, the subjects adopt many guises. The more one seeks, the less one obtains; the more one prohibits, the less one prevails. To create trouble to resolve trouble is like fanning a fire to prevent it from burning. To generate peril through cunning and then rely on cunning to guard against it is like stirring water and hoping for clarity.

Laozi said, "If a ruler favors benevolence, he rewards those without merit and pardons the guilty. If he favors punishment, he dismisses the meritorious and condemns the innocent. Without preferences or aversions, he metes out punishment without resentment and bestows favors without expectation. He follows the plumb line and levels himself by the standard, remaining uninvolved like heaven and earth. How could he not cover and sustain, harmonizing all? To unite and reconcile is the role of the ruler; to distinguish and punish is the function of the law. When the people accept punishment without resentment, this is called the Dao and virtue.

Laozi said, "Under heaven, right and wrong are never fixed. Each age approves what it deems good and condemns what it loathes. Those who seek what is right do not seek the principle of the Dao but what aligns with themselves. They do not reject wickedness but what contradicts their hearts. Now, if I wished to choose what is right and abide by it, to select what is wrong and discard it, I would not know what the world calls right or wrong. Thus, governing a great state is like frying a small fish—do not stir it.

Those who rush to conform speak to flatter and grow closer, yet when their counsel is sound, they are met with suspicion. Now, if I wished to rectify myself and await the world’s response, how would I know what the age expects of me? If I raced with the crowd, it would be like fleeing the rain—nowhere to go without getting drenched. To desire emptiness yet be unable to attain it—only one who does not strive for emptiness yet naturally embodies it achieves what they seek without fail.

Thus, one who penetrates the Dao is like a chariot’s axle: it does not move itself yet, with the wheel, travels a thousand miles, turning endlessly on the infinite plain. Therefore, the sage embodies the Dao, returning to the ultimate and unchanging, awaiting transformation. Moving yet without action.

Laozi said, "A state that wages frequent wars and achieves repeated victories will surely perish. Frequent wars exhaust the people; repeated victories make the ruler arrogant. An arrogant ruler indulges without restraint, pushing things to extremes; an exhausted people grow resentful, their grievances reaching their limit. When both ruler and people are at their extremes, ruin is inevitable. Thus, to withdraw when one’s work is done is the Way of Heaven."

King Ping asked Wenzi, "I have heard that you attained the Dao from Lao Dan. Yet even worthy men, though possessed of the Dao, encounter eras of chaos. With the authority of one man, how can they transform a long-corrupted people?"

Wenzi replied, "The Dao and virtue correct the crooked to make it straight, quell disorder to restore order, and refine excess to return to simplicity. When pure virtue revives, the world finds peace—all hinges on the one man. The ruler is the people’s teacher; the superior is the inferior’s model. If the superior embodies beauty, the inferior emulates it. If the superior possesses the Dao and virtue, the inferior cultivates benevolence and righteousness. With benevolence and righteousness below, there can be no age of chaos.

Accumulated virtue makes a king; accumulated resentment makes ruin. Piled stones form a mountain; gathered waters form a sea. Nothing is accomplished without accumulation. One who accumulates the Dao and virtue gains the favor of heaven, the aid of earth, the assistance of spirits. Phoenixes soar in his courtyard; qilin roam his outskirts; dragons dwell in his ponds. Thus, to govern the world with the Dao is to be the world’s virtue; to govern without the Dao is to be the world’s scourge. To set oneself against the world as an enemy is to court destruction—longevity is unattainable."

By Du Daojian of the Song Dynasty
"On Supreme Virtue"

The old commentary states: "Supreme virtue" refers to the virtuous rulers of their time. The Dao of the Three Dynasties has declined, and the virtue of the Five Hegemons has waned. Thus, it is fitting to cultivate virtue to bring the world into submission. Merit can be seen, and virtue can be revered—hence it is called "supreme virtue."

Laozi said: The ruler is the heart of the state. When the heart is ordered, the hundred limbs are at peace; when the heart is disturbed, the hundred limbs are in chaos.

The old commentary states: Governing the state lies in the ruler’s clarity; when clear, the myriad people delight in their work. Cultivating the self lies in rectifying the heart; when rectified, the hundred limbs rest in their proper place.

Thus, when the self is ordered, the limbs are free from affliction.
The old commentary states: Without illness or suffering.

When the state is ordered, ruler and minister forget one another.
The old commentary states: Without anxiety or care.

The *Zuan Yi* states: Virtue is one, yet it has two aspects. Nurturing the myriad things is the virtue of heaven; cherishing and nourishing the hundred clans is the virtue of the ruler. The ruler is the heart of the state. When the ruler possesses virtue, the heart is expansive, the body at ease, the qi unconfused, and the self is naturally ordered. Governing the state is like cultivating the self. When ruler and minister are at peace, can the state fail to be ordered? Thus it is said: "Supreme virtue does not act as virtue"—this means possessing virtue without relying on it as virtue, and so virtue is truly present.

Lord Lao studied under Chang Cong.
The old commentary states: The teacher of Lord Lao, surnamed Chang, named Cong. Lord Lao himself said he received instruction from his teacher, whose words were thus: "See the ancient and embrace softness."
*Editor’s note: The Ming printed edition reads "ancient" as "tongue."*
The old commentary states: Seeing the ancient Dao, one embraces the feminine and yielding. The character for "ancient" was originally written as "tongue," which also signifies softness.

Gaze up at the eaves and trees.
The old commentary states: Cherishing the fleeting light of time.

Retiring, one gazes upon the river.
*Editor’s note: The Ming printed edition reads "目" as "因," an error for "目."*
The old commentary states: Lamenting that all things in passage never cease.

Observing one’s shadow, one knows to hold to what comes after.
The old commentary states: Not preceding things.
Thus the sage is empty and non-contending, following the constant and remaining behind rather than ahead—like stacked firewood, where what is kindled later lies above.
The old commentary states: What comes after is first; what is below is above. This is the constant principle of things. He who seeks to be first among others cannot be first.

Zuan Yi: Chang Cong was a sage of antiquity. Laozi studied under Chang Cong as Confucius studied under Laozi. Laozi perceived the Dao with his eyes and spirit, thus able to "see the ancient and embrace softness" and "observe his shadow and know to hold to what comes after." Therefore, the sage follows the empty and non-contending, neither striving nor daring to be first. This is called "supreme virtue."

Laozi said: The clapper sounds and destroys itself; the candle burns and consumes itself. The patterns of tigers and leopards invite arrows; the agility of gibbons and monkeys brings capture. Thus the valiant perish through strength, the eloquent are ensnared by their wit, and those who rely on knowledge know only what can be known, not what cannot.
*Editor’s note: The Ming printed edition omits the character "而" in the phrase "而未能以智不知."*
The old commentary states: This is to say that ability harms oneself, while inability preserves oneself; knowledge destroys oneself, while ignorance sustains oneself.

Thus, courage in a single ability or discernment in a single argument may suffice for narrow persuasion but not for broad response.
The old commentary states: Holding to the courage of a common man cannot govern the multitude; clinging to a corner’s argument is not the way of thoroughfare.

Zuan Yi: People value virtue, not excessive knowledge. With too much knowledge, one strays from oneself and returns to oneself—rarely does this not bring harm. The patterns of tigers and leopards invite arrows; the agility of gibbons and monkeys brings capture. The valiant die by their strength, the wise are ensnared by their eloquence—this is fitting. Only he who does not rely on knowledge to know but on knowledge to *not* know is not confined to one corner but responds broadly.

Laozi said: The Dao takes non-being as its essence.
The old commentary states: The essence of the Dao is emptiness and non-being—what is called subtle and wondrous.

What is seen but has no form, heard but makes no sound, is called "dark and obscure." Yet "dark and obscure" is how the Dao is discussed, not the Dao itself.
The old commentary states: Like the fish-trap is for catching fish but is not the fish, words discuss the Dao but are not the Dao.

The Dao is perceived by inward reflection.
The old commentary states: Turning the ear inward and gazing within, one finds it within oneself.

Thus, one who does not indulge in petty learning does not fall into great delusion; one who does not indulge in petty cleverness does not fall into great folly.
*Editor’s note: The Ming printed edition reads "不小学" as "不小觉."*
The old commentary states: Clutching a firefly’s glow to compare with the sun—what delusion could be greater? Holding a pebble to match a piece of jade—what folly could be greater?

Do not mirror yourself in flowing waters but in still waters, for their inner stillness keeps them from outward disturbance.
The old commentary states: When the mind’s dust scatters outward, it flows turbid and remains dim; when water’s nature is inwardly empty, it is deep and clear, mirroring itself.

When the moon is full, the sun’s light is diminished. Time cannot be entrusted to the yang; when the sun rises, the stars fade and cannot compete with its brilliance. The branch cannot be stronger than the trunk; the top cannot outweigh the bottom without risking collapse.
The old commentary states: This means that the great ruler issues commands, and petty men should not be employed. If they are, it is like yin usurping the sun’s light. The root and branch should be proportionate, the noble and base in their proper places—then there will be no danger of toppling or ruin.

A single abyss does not harbor two dragons; a single female does not mate with two males. Where there is oneness, there is stability; where there are two, there is strife.
The old commentary states: When the ruler is one, the state is at peace; when the lord is one, the heart is at ease.

Jade lies in the mountain, and the grass and trees are moistened; pearls form in the deep, and the banks do not wither.
The old commentary states: Mountains and rivers conceal jade and become lush; the noble accumulates virtue and radiates brilliance.

The earthworm has no strong sinews or sharp claws and teeth, yet above it eats the dry clods, below it drinks the yellow springs—all through the unity of its mind.
*Editor’s note: The Ming printed edition reads "上食晞块" as "上食晞堁."*
The old commentary states: When the earthworm is hungry, it eats soil; when thirsty, it drinks water—it has no other concerns, so it needs no sinews or claws. When a person unifies the mind and guards the Dao, what need is there for fame or profit to feel content?

Zuan Yi: The Dao takes non-being as its essence, so it can coexist with all things. Things take form as their function, so they cannot stand together. Non-being as essence brings unity and stability; form as function brings duality and strife. Yet there are distinctions between great and small, divisions between ruler and minister. If the ruler embraces the Dao and holds to virtue, never claiming them as his own—this is why the Dao is great and virtue enduring. Who in the world would dare to contend with such strength?

Clarity brings illumination: a cup of water can reveal the pupil of the eye. Turbidity brings harm: a river’s waters cannot reveal Mount Tai.
The old commentary states: Though small, clarity can reflect the finest details; though vast, turbidity cannot reveal even mountains and peaks.

Orchids and iris do not cease to be fragrant because no one wears them; a boat does not sink in rivers and seas because no one rides it. The noble person practices the Dao not because no one knows him but because it is his nature to do so.
The old commentary states: The fragrance of orchids and iris is their nature—they cannot but be fragrant. The noble person’s practice of goodness is the Dao—he cannot but act.

Entering the turbid with clarity brings distress and disgrace; entering the clear with turbidity brings ruin and collapse.
The old commentary states: The worthy and the foolish do not stand together; the clear and the turbid are not the same vessel.

hang, named Cong. Lord Lao himself said he received instruction from his teacher, whose words were thus: "See the ancient and embrace softness."
*Editor’s note: The Ming printed edition reads "ancient" as "tongue."*
The old commentary states: Seeing the ancient Dao, one embraces the feminine and yielding. The character for "ancient" was originally written as "tongue," which also signifies softness.

The old commentary states: Cherishing the fleeting light of time.

chunks.original_text: 天二气即成虹地二气即泄藏人二气即生病 旧注三才之道所贵主一 阴阳不能常且冬且夏月不知昼日不知夜 旧注冬夏不可差跌昼夜不相干犯 川广者鱼大山高者木修地广者德厚 旧注川不广不能生巨鳞智不周不能达至理故知非厚德不能深知而远见 故鱼不可以无饵钓兽不可以空器召 旧注物不可以端坐致道不可以无人 山有猛兽林木为之不斩园有螫虫葵藿为之不采国有贤臣折冲千里 旧注猛兽螫虫犹庇及草木贤人君子自然辅佑君民也 通于道者若车轴转于毂中不运于己与之致于千里终而复始转于无穷之原也【案原本原作厚今据明刋本改正】 旧注前巳释矣 故举枉与直何如不得举直与枉勿与遂往 旧注以释符言篇也 缵义水清鉴影心清鉴物明之故也浊则昏矣君子小人势不两立冬寒夏暑时不并行时并行则灾疠生势两立则祸患作虽然为君子者岂以小人在位道不可行而终不出乎 有鸟将来张罗而待之得鸟者罗之一目今为一目之罗则无时得鸟 旧注任一人之才难以御众一目之罗无由获鸟 故事或不可前规物或不可预虑故圣人畜道待时也旧注夫圣人其行也天其动也时未至即守道时之来即修之文王之兴周道高祖之盛汉业也 欲致鱼者先通谷欲求鸟者先树木水积而鱼聚木茂而鸟集为鱼得者非挈而入渊也为猨得者非负而上木也纵之所利而已 旧注夫君臣相为用也由鱼之投水鸟之依林纵其所利不召而来明君处世而忠贤自至也 足所践者浅然待所不践而后能行心所知者然待所不知而后能明 旧注足所践者少其不践者多心所知者寡其不知者众以不用而能成其用不知而能全其知也 川竭而谷虚丘夷而渊塞唇亡而齿寒河水深其壤在山【案明刋本其壤在山其字作而字】 旧注此善言君民相依犹山川相通河水深则膏壤在山君厚敛则民货匮乏上有所求下有所竭民力殚而君位危则唇亡齿寒之义者是也 水静则清清则平平即易易见物之形形不可以为正【案形不可以为正句明刋本作形不可并故可以为正】 旧注谓元首既明犹止水之清深鉴物情善恶之状无逃幽察人情平和之政斯布也 缵义知有用之不可与言政治国者要在一人非众人则不能治欲得贤而不先养士可乎是以圣人畜道待时得人则兴未有不为我用者也 使叶落者风揺之也使水浊者物挠之也 旧注风不揺而木自落物常挠而水自清未之有也 璧瑗之器礛【音蓝】防之功也镆铘之断割砥砺之力也旧注言良玉宝剑虽有美质终假砥砺之功成乎奇器君子贤人虽有才质终假师匠方成其业也 防与骥致千里而不飞无裹粮之资而不饥 旧注国所托者贤则所存者大坐而无忧物所附者良则所致者远疾而不劳 狡兔得而猎犬烹 旧注必然之势 高鸟尽而良弓藏 旧注不见用也 名成功遂身退天道然也 旧注审进退之宜尽穷通之数抱道守德全身保名可谓贤也 怒出于不怒为出于不为视于无有则得所见听于无声则得所闻 旧注人之性本无怒怒出于有事人之性本无为为出于有欲知怒之为过为之是非故内视见于无形反听致于无声者谓却照本性而无声无形无怒无为所贵见于无非谓见于有也 飞鸟反乡兔走归窟狐死首丘寒螀得木各依其所生旧注物不忘本人或违道 缵义道可独行不可以独擅人健走日不百里而罢得良马则千里可致怒出于不怒文武所以安天下之民为尧舜所以成垂衣之治为国家而善用人者民孰不知归乎

The two qi of heaven form the rainbow; the two qi of earth leak and store; the two qi of man generate illness. The old commentary states: The Dao of the Three Powers values unity above all. Yin and yang cannot be both winter and summer at once; the moon cannot know day, nor the sun know night. The old commentary states: Winter and summer cannot be confused; day and night do not encroach upon one another.

Where rivers are broad, fish grow large; where mountains are high, trees grow tall; where the land is vast, virtue is profound. The old commentary states: If rivers are not broad, they cannot nurture giant scales; if wisdom is not comprehensive, it cannot reach the ultimate principle. Thus, one knows that without profound virtue, one cannot deeply understand or see far.

Therefore, fish cannot be caught without bait; beasts cannot be summoned with empty vessels. The old commentary states: Things cannot be obtained by sitting idly; the Dao cannot be attained without the proper means.

Where mountains have fierce beasts, their forests remain uncut; where gardens have stinging insects, their mallows and beans remain unpicked; where a state has worthy ministers, it repels enemies a thousand *li* away. The old commentary states: Fierce beasts and stinging insects still shelter grass and trees; worthy and noble persons naturally aid their lord and people.

One who is attuned to the Dao is like a wheel’s axle turning within the hub: it does not move itself, yet with it, one travels a thousand *li*, ever returning to the beginning, revolving in an inexhaustible source. The old commentary states: This has been explained previously.

Thus, to lift the crooked while ignoring the straight—how can this suffice? Do not lift the straight while abandoning the crooked; do not proceed once the goal is achieved. The old commentary states: This explains the "Tallying Words" chapter.

Water’s clarity mirrors reflections; the heart’s clarity mirrors things with clarity. When turbid, all is obscured. The noble and the petty cannot stand together; winter’s cold and summer’s heat cannot coexist. If they do, disasters and plagues arise; if both hold power, calamities ensue. Yet how can the noble, seeing the petty in office and the Dao obstructed, forever remain withdrawn?

A bird is about to arrive, and one sets a net to await it. The bird is caught by a single mesh of the net—yet if one sets a net of but one mesh, the bird will never be caught. The old commentary states: Relying on one person’s talent is insufficient to govern the many; a net of one mesh cannot catch birds.

Thus, some matters cannot be planned in advance; some things cannot be foreseen. Therefore, the sage accumulates the Dao and awaits the moment. The old commentary states: The sage’s conduct follows heaven; his actions follow the times. When the time has not come, he guards the Dao; when it arrives, he acts. This is how King Wen rose to establish the Zhou and how Emperor Gaozu flourished to build the Han.

To attract fish, first clear the valley streams; to seek birds, first plant trees. Water gathers, and fish assemble; trees flourish, and birds gather. To obtain fish, one does not carry them into the depths; to obtain apes, one does not carry them up the trees. One simply follows what benefits them. The old commentary states: The mutual reliance of lord and minister is like fish returning to water and birds nesting in trees. Following what benefits them, they come unbidden. Thus, a wise ruler in the world naturally draws loyal worthies.

What the feet tread is shallow, yet one must await what they do not tread to walk; what the heart knows is limited, yet one must await what it does not know to attain clarity. The old commentary states: What the feet tread is little; what they do not tread is much. What the heart knows is few; what it does not know is many. By not using what is unused, its use is perfected; by not knowing what is unknown, its knowledge is preserved.

When rivers run dry, valleys empty; when hills are leveled, deep pools fill; when lips are gone, teeth grow cold; when river waters run deep, fertile soil remains in the mountains. The old commentary states: This well illustrates how lord and people depend on one another, just as mountains and rivers connect. When river waters run deep, rich soil remains in the mountains; when the lord levies heavily, the people’s wealth is exhausted. When those above demand, those below are depleted. When the people’s strength is spent, the lord’s position is imperiled—this is the meaning of "when lips are gone, teeth grow cold."

When water is still, it is clear; when clear, it is level; when level, it is easy to see the forms of things. Yet forms cannot be taken as the standard. The old commentary states: When the ruler is enlightened, it is like still water’s clarity, deeply reflecting the true nature of things—good and evil cannot escape its scrutiny. When governance is even and harmonious, its policies spread.

To summarize: Those who know the essentials of governance understand that ruling a state depends on one person, not the many. Without first cultivating scholars, can one obtain worthies? Thus, the sage accumulates the Dao and awaits the moment. When the right person is found, the state flourishes—none will fail to serve him.

Leaves fall because the wind shakes them; water grows turbid because things disturb it. The old commentary states: Without wind, trees shed leaves on their own; without disturbance, water remains clear—this has never been otherwise.

The beauty of jade and fine rings comes from the polishing of *jian* stone; the sharpness of *Moye* and *Yanyue* swords comes from the grinding of whetstones. The old commentary states: Even fine jade and precious swords, though naturally excellent, ultimately rely on the work of whetstones to become extraordinary implements. Likewise, though the noble and worthy possess talent and quality, they ultimately rely on teachers and masters to perfect their work.

Fang Yu and Ji could travel a thousand *li* without flying; without provisions, they did not hunger. The old commentary states: When a state relies on worthies, its achievements are great, and it rests without worry. When things attach to the good, their reach is far, and they move swiftly without labor.

When the cunning hare is caught, the hunting dog is cooked. The old commentary states: This is the inevitable outcome.

When the high-flying birds are gone, the fine bow is put away. The old commentary states: It is no longer used.

When fame is achieved and success attained, one retreats—this is the Way of Heaven. The old commentary states: One who understands the proper times for advance and retreat, who exhausts the principles of rise and fall, who embraces the Dao and guards virtue, preserving his person and protecting his name—such a one may be called worthy.

Anger arises from non-anger; action arises from non-action. Seeing in the absence of forms, one obtains true vision; hearing in the absence of sound, one obtains true hearing. The old commentary states: Human nature is originally without anger—anger arises from circumstances. Human nature is originally without action—action arises from desires. To know that anger is excessive and action is improper, one must inwardly see what has no form and reverse-hear what has no sound. This means returning to one’s original nature, where there is no sound, no form, no anger, no action. What is valued is seeing what is not there—seeing what is.

Flying birds return to their homeland; hares run back to their burrows; foxes die with their heads toward the hills; cold cicadas cling to trees—each depends on its origin. The old commentary states: Creatures do not forget their roots; people, however, may stray from the Dao.

To summarize: The Dao can be practiced alone, but it cannot be monopolized alone. A man may walk vigorously, yet after a hundred *li*, he tires. With a fine horse, a thousand *li* can be reached. Anger arises from non-anger—this is how Kings Wen and Wu pacified the world’s people. Action arises from non-action—this is how Yao and Shun achieved governance without effort. For the state, those who skillfully employ others—how could the people not know where to return?

To obtain fish, one does not carry them into the depths; to obtain apes, one does not carry them up the trees. One simply follows what benefits them. The old commentary states: The mutual reliance of lord and minister is like fish returning to water and birds nesting in trees. Following what benefits them, they come unbidden. Thus, a wise ruler in the world naturally draws loyal worthies.

What the feet tread is shallow, yet one must await what they do not tread to walk; what the heart knows is limited, yet one must await what it does not know to attain clarity. The old commentary states: What the feet tread is little; what they do not tread is much. What the heart knows is few; what it does not know is many. By not using what is unused, its use is perfected; by not knowing what is unknown, its knowledge is preserved.

chunks.original_text: 水火相憎鼎鬲在其间五味以和骨肉相爱也谗人间之父子相危也 旧注言物性有相反虽水火相攻用之有方则致和父子相爱谗慝间之则见疑贤者不可不察也 犬豕不择器而食愈肥其体故近死 旧注此明小人苟希名利虽且贵而终否贤者畜道待时虽暂否而终泰也 凤皇翔于千仞莫之能致椎固百内而不能自椽旧注【陟坏反未详】 目见百步之外而不能见其眦 旧注希大者亡其细见远者遗其近 因高为山即安而不危因下为渊则鱼鳖归焉【案明刋本作即深而鱼鳖归焉】 旧注因其所易人不劳而自成利其所习物不召而自至 沟池潦即溢旱即枯河海之源渊而不竭【案渊而不竭句明刋本作渊深而不竭】 旧注小器与之则易满取之则易竭大量益之而不盈酌之而不绝也 鳖无耳而目不可以蔽精于明也瞽无目而耳不可以蔽精于听也【案精于听也句明刋本听作聪】 旧注各利一原莫能相假 混混之水浊可以濯吾足乎泠泠之水清可以濯吾缨乎 旧注言清浊无遗贤愚并用但量能授任称物随机也 防【音药】之为缟也或为冠或为【音袜】 旧注言所用不定也 冠即戴枝之即足碾之 旧注无乖其分各全其要 缵义人无常是物无常非气顺则合气逆则离火炎上水润下鼎鬲和之即既济之功成父主慈子主孝谗人间之即参商之怨起犬豕体肥近于死凤皇高飞莫能致清斯濯缨浊斯濯足不能洁已而为物污者可不审诸 金之势胜木一刃不能残一林土之势胜水一掬不能塞江河水之势胜火一酌不能救一车之薪 旧注谕一人之直不能移众枉任一人之智不能化群迷也 冬有雷夏有雹寒暑不变其节霜雪麃麃 旧注麃碑休反儦也 日出而流 旧注冬雷夏雹寒暑不能全其节太阳回照霜雪不能固其质也 倾易覆也倚易軵【音附】也 几易助也湿易雨也 旧注贤者亲善愚者亲恶其势易附其事易染也 兰芷以芳不得见霜蟾蜍辟兵寿在五月之望 旧注斯皆有用而见害曷若无名以全身案万毕术蟾蜍五月中杀涂五兵入军阵而不伤 精泄者中易残 旧注精华发于内而枝干凋于外也 华非其时者不可食 旧注内非时而食必病时非义而取必害 缵义生克制伏固有定分力小任大未有不返受其制者木胜金水胜土火胜水终非其性夫冬雷夏雹终非其时曾不朝夕之久人其可不自量乎 舌之与齿孰先弊焉绳之与矢孰先直焉 旧注刚者虽坚而致弊柔者善屈而正物 使影曲者形也使响浊者声也 旧注形端必无曲影言善必无恶响 与死同病者难为良医与亡国同道者不可为忠谋旧注必死之病医虽良而不救必亡之国臣虽忠而难存 使倡吹竽使工捻窍虽中节不可使决君形亡焉旧注倡乐人也工制器人也盖言倡者吹竽工者捻窍曲节虽中律终动用相违心手莫应何能使决言其主君形亡也 聋者不歌无以自乐盲者不观无以接物 旧注声不通于耳绝想其乐色不见其目息观于心
chunks.translated_text:
Water and fire despise each other, yet the tripod stands between them, harmonizing the five flavors; bones and flesh love one another, yet slanderers sow discord between them, endangering father and son. The old commentary states: The natures of things may be opposed—though water and fire attack each other, when used with proper method, they achieve harmony. Father and son love one another, yet slander and malice sow suspicion between them. The worthy cannot but be discerning.

Dogs and swine eat from any vessel and grow fat, hastening their death. The old commentary states: This illustrates how petty men, in their eagerness for fame and profit, may rise for a time but ultimately fall, while the worthy cultivate the Way and await their moment, enduring temporary setbacks to achieve lasting success.

The phoenix soars a thousand fathoms high, yet none can bring it down; the hammer strikes a hundred times within, yet cannot straighten itself. The old commentary notes: *[Zhì huài, meaning unclear.]*
The eye sees a hundred paces away yet cannot see its own lashes. The old commentary states: Those who seek greatness neglect the small; those who see far overlook what is near.

Build upon height to make a mountain, and it stands firm without peril; delve into depth to make a deep pool, and fish and turtles gather there. *[According to the Ming printed edition: "it deepens, and fish and turtles gather there."]*
The old commentary states: By following what comes easily, one labors not, yet success is achieved; by relying on what is familiar, things come unbidden.

Ditches and ponds overflow when full and dry up in drought, but the source of rivers and seas is deep and inexhaustible. *[According to the Ming printed edition: "deep and inexhaustible."]*
The old commentary states: Small vessels fill quickly when filled and empty quickly when drawn from, but a great measure may be added to without overflowing and drawn from without depletion.

The soft-shelled turtle has no ears, yet its eyes cannot be obscured, for it is keen in clarity; the blind have no eyes, yet their ears cannot be deceived, for they are sharp in hearing. *[According to the Ming printed edition: "sharp in hearing."]*
The old commentary states: Each excels in its own faculty; none can borrow from the other.

Can turbid, swirling waters be used to wash my feet? Can clear, cool waters be used to rinse my cap strings?
The old commentary states: This speaks of neither rejecting the muddy nor favoring the clear—both worthy and unworthy are employed, but each is given tasks according to ability and matched to their nature.

Silk floss may become either a cap or a sock. *[Pronounced "wà."]*
The old commentary states: Its use is not fixed.
A cap is worn on the head, while socks are trampled underfoot.
The old commentary states: There is no conflict in their roles; each fulfills its proper function.

To continue the meaning: People have no constant right, things have no constant wrong. When qi flows in accord, they unite; when qi flows in opposition, they part. Fire flames upward, water moistens downward—when the tripod harmonizes them, the work of "Completion" is achieved. When a father is kind and a son filial, slanderers sow discord, and the enmity of Shen and Shang arises. Dogs and swine grow fat and near death; the phoenix soars high, beyond reach. Clear waters rinse cap strings, turbid waters wash feet—yet those who cannot purify themselves and instead soil others should take heed.

The power of metal overcomes wood, yet a single blade cannot fell a forest; the power of earth overcomes water, yet a handful cannot dam rivers and streams; the power of water overcomes fire, yet a ladle cannot extinguish a cartload of kindling.
The old commentary states: This illustrates how one man’s uprightness cannot correct many crooked ways, nor can one man’s wisdom enlighten a multitude of delusions.

In winter, there is thunder; in summer, there is hail. Cold and heat do not alter their seasons, and frost and snow fall thickly. *[Pronounced "biāo," meaning "abundant."]*
The old commentary states: *[Biāo, from *bēi xiū*, meaning "dense."]*
The sun rises and flows onward.
The old commentary states: Winter thunder and summer hail cannot fully disrupt the seasons; the sun’s turning light cannot be fixed by frost and snow.

Collapse is easy to overturn; leaning is easy to topple. *[Pronounced "fǔ."]*
Nearness is easy to assist; dampness is easy to rain upon.
The old commentary states: The worthy draw near to the good, while the foolish draw near to the wicked—their influence is easily followed, their affairs easily tainted.

Orchids and angelica are fragrant, yet when touched by frost, toads and toads alone repel weapons and live long—on the full moon of the fifth month. *[According to the *Wanbi Shu*: "On the fifth month’s full moon, kill a toad and apply its blood to weapons; entering battle, one will not be harmed."]*
The old commentary states: These all have their uses yet suffer harm—how much better to remain nameless and preserve oneself.

Those who dissipate their essence are easily broken within.
The old commentary states: When inner essence is expended, outer branches and trunk wither.

Fruit that blooms out of season should not be eaten.
The old commentary states: To eat what is not in season brings illness; to take what is not in accord with right brings harm.

To continue the meaning: The mutual overcoming of the Five Phases has its fixed order. When the weak take on what is too great, none do not in the end suffer its control. Wood overcomes metal, water overcomes earth, fire overcomes water—yet these are not their true natures. Winter thunder and summer hail are not their proper seasons, and their duration is not even a morning or evening. How can one fail to measure oneself?

Which fails first, the tongue or the teeth? Which remains straight longer, the rope or the arrow?
The old commentary states: The hard, though firm, comes to ruin; the soft, though yielding, sets things right.

It is form that makes the shadow crooked; it is sound that makes the echo muddy.
The old commentary states: When form is upright, the shadow cannot be crooked; when words are good, the echo cannot be bad.

Those who share the same illness as the dead are difficult to cure; those who follow the same path as a ruined state cannot offer loyal counsel.
The old commentary states: A fatal illness cannot be saved, even by a skilled physician; a doomed state cannot be preserved, even by a loyal minister.

Have musicians play the *yu*; have craftsmen shape the holes—though they may hit the notes, they cannot be made to judge the ruler’s form, for it is lost.
The old commentary states: The musician is the performer; the craftsman shapes instruments. This speaks of musicians playing the *yu* and craftsmen shaping the holes—though the rhythm may be correct, their functions differ. Heart and hand do not respond; how can they judge? This means the ruler’s form is lost.

The deaf do not sing, for they have no way to delight themselves; the blind do not gaze, for they have no way to engage with things.
The old commentary states: Sound does not reach the ears, so they cut off thoughts of joy; color does not meet the eyes, so they cease observation in the heart.

chunks.original_text: 步于林者不得直道行于险者不得履绳 旧注步林不求阡陌务于通足履险不循规矩事在济危也 海内其所出故能大 旧注生而不绝用而无穷故为大也 缵义处非其地依非其人难矣哉齿刚先缺矢劲先折与死同病难于为良医与亡国同道不可为忠谋君不用道而臣强之谋出二心功可成乎 日不并出狐不二雄神龙不匹猛兽不群鸷鸟不双旧注斯皆独立不群故能为百兽众禽之长也 盖非橑不蔽日轮非辐不追疾盖轮未足恃也 旧注言事物相假不可偏任也 张弓而射非不能发矢之为射十分之一 旧注弓虽劲无不能中的君虽圣非忠无以济于业凡为射者甚众至于求中者十分无一犹干禄者不少至于求贤者万分无二 饥马在廐漠然无声投刍其旁争心乃生 旧注乏刍豢者投之乃争渴名位者居之必竞故君子让其禄小人竞其位也 三寸之管无当天下不能满十石而有塞百斗而足旧注论贪者无厌而莫定由器之无底而难满 循绳而断即不过悬衡而量即不差悬古法以有时而遂杖格之属有时而施是而行之谓之断非而行之谓之乱 旧注循绳而动物不能越悬衡为制事无不当古今既殊法度亦异适时而治滞方则乱 缵义日不并出神龙不匹猛兽不群况于人乎橑以张盖轴以转轮君臣相资之道也饥马争刍赏不可滥循绳而断法无过差古法杖格用之以时在乎行之者耳 农夫劳而君子养愚者言而智者择 旧注耕也劳在其中学也禄在其中 见之明白处之如玉石见之黯【乌感切】黣【音昧】必留其谋旧注事理明白居然可分固无疑焉间见卤莽自难情晓宜其谋矣 百星之明不如一月之光十牖毕开不如一户之明旧注小人虽众不足可任贤士虽寡得一有余文王得吕望高祖得子房其在多乎 蝮蛇不可为足虎不可为翼 旧注人无全能物不双美
chunks.translated_text:
One who walks through the forest cannot take the straight path; one who travels through peril cannot tread the plumb line.
The old commentary states: Walking through the forest, one does not seek the crisscrossing paths but focuses on moving forward; treading through peril, one does not follow the carpenter’s square and compass but acts to overcome danger.

What the seas and lands produce endures, and thus can be great.
The old commentary states: Born without ceasing, used without exhaustion—thus it is called great.

To carry on virtue in a place not one’s own, to rely on those not one’s kin—how difficult this is! Teeth, though hard, break first; arrows, though strong, snap first. This is like a fatal illness where even a skilled physician cannot save, or a doomed state where even a loyal minister cannot preserve.
When a ruler abandons the Dao and a minister forces his counsel, their minds diverge—can success be achieved?

The sun does not rise twice; the fox does not have two alphas. The spirit-dragon does not pair; fierce beasts do not flock. Birds of prey do not fly in pairs.
The old commentary states: These all stand alone and do not flock, thus they become leaders of the hundred beasts and flocks of birds.

Without the canopy’s ribs, the sun’s wheel cannot be shaded; without the spokes, swiftness cannot be pursued. Yet the wheel alone is not sufficient to rely upon.
The old commentary states: This speaks of how things mutually depend on one another and cannot be entrusted to one side alone.

To draw a bow and shoot, without the bowstring the arrow cannot be loosed—such is but one-tenth of archery.
The old commentary states: Though the bow may be strong, without the bowstring it cannot hit the mark. Though the ruler may be sagely, without loyalty, nothing can be accomplished in governance. Among all who draw the bow, many seek to shoot, but those who truly aim to hit the mark are but one in ten. So too are those who seek office plentiful, but those who seek worthiness are as rare as one in ten thousand.

A starving horse in the stable makes no sound; cast fodder beside it, and its competitive heart arises.
The old commentary states: When one lacking fodder is given it, they will contend. Those thirsting for fame and position, once given it, will surely compete. Thus the noble person yields their emolument, while the petty person vies for rank.

A three-inch tube without a base cannot hold even ten *shi* of the world’s grain, yet with a stopper, it can hold a hundred *dou*.
The old commentary states: This speaks of the insatiable greed of the avaricious, which has no limit, just as a vessel without a bottom is difficult to fill.

Cutting along the plumb line will not err; measuring with the suspended balance will not miscalculate. Suspending the ancient methods of the *jun* and *zhuo* may at times succeed, while implements like the staff and cangue may at times be applied. To act in accord with this is called judgment; to act contrary to it is called chaos.
The old commentary states: Moving in accord with the plumb line, nothing can transgress it; establishing measures with the suspended balance, nothing will be amiss. As ancient and modern times differ, so too do laws and standards. Adapting to the times brings order; clinging to obsolete methods brings chaos.

To carry on virtue, the sun does not rise twice, the spirit-dragon does not pair, fierce beasts do not flock—how much more so for humans! The ribs support the canopy; the axle turns the wheel—this is the Dao of mutual reliance between ruler and minister. A starving horse contends for fodder; rewards must not be recklessly bestowed. Cutting along the plumb line, the law does not err; ancient methods and implements are applied in their proper time—it lies in the hands of those who enact them.

The farmer toils while the noble person is nourished; the foolish speak while the wise select.
The old commentary states: In plowing, toil lies within; in learning, emolument lies within.

To see clearly is to handle things as jade and stone; to see dimly and obscurely is to surely retain one’s schemes.
The old commentary states: When the principles of affairs are clear, they can be distinctly divided without doubt. But when perception is crude and hasty, understanding becomes difficult, and thus one’s schemes are preserved.

The brightness of a hundred stars does not equal the light of a single moon; ten windows fully opened do not equal the brightness of one door.
The old commentary states: Though petty persons may be many, they are not sufficient to be entrusted; though a worthy person may be few, one is more than enough. King Wen obtained Lü Wang; Gaozu obtained Zhang Liang—does it lie in numbers?

The venomous snake cannot be given feet; the tiger cannot be given wings.
The old commentary states: No person is perfectly capable; no thing is doubly excellent.
chunks.overlap_context:
musicians playing the *yu* and craftsmen shaping the holes—though the rhythm may be correct, their functions differ. Heart and hand do not respond; how can they judge? This means the ruler’s form is lost.

The deaf do not sing, for they have no way to delight themselves; the blind do not gaze, for they have no way to engage with things.
The old commentary states: Sound does not reach the ears, so they cut off thoughts of joy; color does not meet the eyes, so they cease observation in the heart.

chunks.original_text: 今有六尺之席【案原本席作广据明刋本改正】卧而越之下才不难立而逾之上才不易势施异也 旧注明人才不等也于彼则通于此则塞所能有异故也 助祭者得尝救斗者得伤 旧注见善蒙恵遇恶有伤 蔽于不祥之木为雷霆所扑 旧注蔽不祥之木而天威难逭匿不善之人而国法必诛也 日月欲明浮云蔽之河水欲清沙土秽之丛兰欲修秋风败之人性欲平嗜欲害之蒙尘而欲无眯不可得洁旧注处昏翳之间何以见明居嗜欲之从所染霜霰交下兰蕙难以保其芳沙壤汩流河源无以全其洁 黄金龟纽贤者以为佩土壤布地能者以为富 旧注不识所用虽金玉以为粪土苟知所施虽土壤以为珠玉 故与弱者金玉不如与之尺素 旧注弱与愚弱也与之尺素或可保与之金玉则为害犹小人不可乘大位必至危亡也 缵义农夫不劳君子无以养君子不治农夫其能安乎蛇无足虎无翼不可两得浮云盖日失不在已嗜欲害性病不在人 毂虚而中立三十辐各尽其力使一辐独入众辐皆弃何近远之能至 旧注为车者必假众辐求致远之用治国者亦借群才保久安之业 橘柚有乡萑苇有丛兽同足者相从游鸟同翼者相从翔 旧注同气相召同相求 欲观九州之地足无千里之行无政敎之源而欲为万民上者难矣 旧注观乎九域岂不行而至御万机岂无道而居之也 凶凶者获提提者射 旧注凶凶者恶也提提者群也言群恶相聚必被中伤为人诛获也提音时 故大白若辱广德若不足 旧注明唯白着故似屈辱德不外有若缺少 君子有酒 旧注言其过量 小人鞭缶虽不可好亦可以丑 旧注言君子饮酒之过小人鞭为诫在小人犹不可好君子固可为丑也 缵义皇极居中资八辅而后建车毂虚中借众轴而后行天子中天下而立位万民之上而无政教之原是犹无千里之足欲观九州之地其何以行之惟正位端居百官分职不下堂而天下治矣 人之性便衣丝帛或射之即被甲为所不便以得其便也 旧注御寒即假缯纩临兵即被甲胄相时而动以取其便人之情也 三十辐共一毂各直一凿不得相入犹人臣各守其职也 旧注此意不殊前解 善用人者若蚈【音贤】之足众而不相害若舌之与齿坚柔相磨而不相败 旧注蚈百足虫也言人善用众者其由蚈乎舌之与齿刚柔并任愚智咸收使各循其分不失其材也 石生而坚芷生而芳少而有之长而逾明 旧注此原其性也石坚芷芳由贤者明愚者暗是知坚芳不可夺愚暗亦莫移少而有之长而弥笃也 扶之与提谢之与让得之与失诺之与已相去千里旧注此言邈然悬殊孰云一致者也 缵义作事有法事无不成用人有方人无不济车毂之各直一凿明官事之各有守也蚈足众而不相害由用得其宜矣石坚芷芳随其才而用之则贤者明愚者力成功一也 再生者不获华太早者不须霜而落 旧注再荣不实阳极自零
chunks.translated_text:
Here is the translation:

---

A six-foot mat—lying down, even an inferior talent can cross beneath it; standing, even a superior talent cannot step over it. The difference lies in the circumstances.
The old commentary states: Clearly, people’s talents are unequal. In one situation, they may excel; in another, they may falter. Their abilities differ, and so do their outcomes.

Those who assist in sacrifices may taste the offerings; those who intervene in fights may be wounded.
The old commentary states: When one encounters goodness, one receives its blessings; when one meets evil, one suffers harm.

Sheltering beneath an ill-omened tree, one may be struck by thunder.
The old commentary states: Taking refuge under an ill-omened tree, one cannot escape Heaven’s wrath; harboring an evil person, one will surely face the nation’s law.

The sun and moon wish to shine, but floating clouds obscure them; the river wishes to run clear, but sand and soil pollute it. The orchid wishes to flourish, but autumn winds wither it; human nature wishes to be balanced, but desires harm it. Covered in dust, how can one avoid being blinded? Purity is unattainable.
The old commentary states: Dwelling in darkness, how can one perceive brightness? Living amid desires, what one is tainted by becomes like frost and sleet falling together—how can orchids and irises preserve their fragrance? Sand and mud pollute the flow, so how can the river’s source remain pure?

Gold and jade with tortoise-shell knobs may be worn by the worthy as ornaments; earth and soil may be spread upon the ground, yet the capable consider them wealth.
The old commentary states: Those who do not recognize their use may treat gold and jade as dung; those who know their application may regard earth and soil as jewels.

Thus, giving gold and jade to the weak is not as good as giving them plain silk.
The old commentary states: The weak here refers to the foolish. Giving them plain silk may preserve them, but giving them gold and jade will harm them—just as petty men should not occupy high positions, for it will surely lead to danger and ruin.

If the plowman does not toil, the gentleman has nothing to eat; if the gentleman does not govern, how can the plowman be at peace? A snake cannot have feet, nor a tiger wings—one cannot have both. Floating clouds cover the sun, but the fault does not lie with the sun; desires harm one’s nature, but the illness does not come from others.

A wheel’s hub is hollow at its center, and the thirty spokes each exert their strength. If one spoke were to protrude alone, all the others would be abandoned—how then could it travel near or far?
The old commentary states: A cart must rely on many spokes to achieve its purpose of long travel; governing a state must also depend on many talents to secure lasting peace.

Oranges and pomelos have their native soil; reeds and rushes grow in clusters. Beasts with the same feet travel together; birds with the same wings soar together.
The old commentary states: Those of the same qi summon one another; those of the same kind seek one another.

To observe the land of the Nine Provinces, one cannot do so without traveling a thousand *li*; without the source of governance and teaching, one cannot stand above the myriad people.
The old commentary states: To survey the Nine Domains, how can one arrive without traveling? To govern the myriad affairs, how can one do so without the Dao?

The fierce are hunted; the clustered are shot.
The old commentary states: The fierce are the wicked; the clustered are the many. When the wicked gather, they will surely be struck down and punished. *Ti* (提) is pronounced *shi*.

Thus, the purest white appears tarnished; the greatest virtue seems insufficient.
The old commentary states: Only brightness appears white, so it seems to bear humiliation; virtue does not display itself outwardly, so it appears lacking.

The gentleman has wine—
The old commentary states: This speaks of excess.

The petty man beats the clay pot. Though it cannot be considered good, it can at least serve as a warning.
The old commentary states: The gentleman’s overindulgence in wine is excessive; the petty man’s beating of the clay pot serves as a caution. Even for the petty man, this is not good—how much more shameful is it for the gentleman?

If the August Ultimate resides at the center, it relies on the Eight Assistants to establish itself; if the wheel’s hub is hollow at its center, it depends on the many spokes to move. The Son of Heaven stands at the center of the world, above the myriad people, yet without the source of governance and teaching, it is like having no feet to travel a thousand *li* and observe the land of the Nine Provinces—how can one proceed? Only by rectifying one’s position, sitting upright, and assigning duties to the hundred officials can the world be governed without leaving the hall.

Human nature is suited to wearing silk, yet one may be shot and don armor—what is inconvenient becomes convenient when it serves its purpose.
The old commentary states: To ward off cold, one relies on silk and floss; in battle, one wears armor. One acts according to the time to achieve convenience—this is human nature.

The thirty spokes share one hub, each aligned with its own mortise and unable to encroach upon one another—just as ministers each guard their own duties.
The old commentary states: This meaning is no different from the previous explanation.

One who is skilled in employing others is like the centipede’s many feet, numerous yet not harming one another; like the tongue and teeth, hard and soft rubbing together yet not defeating one another.
The old commentary states: The centipede is a many-footed creature. This speaks of one who is skilled in employing the many—is it not like the centipede? The tongue and teeth work together, hardness and softness both serving, the foolish and the wise all gathered, each following their proper place without losing their abilities.

Stone is born hard; the angelica is born fragrant. To possess these qualities in youth is to become even more radiant with age.
The old commentary states: This speaks of their original nature. Stone is hard, angelica is fragrant—just as the worthy are bright and the foolish are dim. Thus, hardness and fragrance cannot be taken away, nor can foolishness and dimness be altered. To possess these in youth is to become even more steadfast with age.

Supporting and lifting, declining and yielding, gaining and losing, promising and reneging—these differ by a thousand *li*.
The old commentary states: This speaks of their vast and distant disparity—who would say they are the same?

If governance has its methods, no affair will fail; if employing people has its principles, no one will be unhelpful. The wheel’s spokes each align with their own mortise—this clarifies that officials each have their own duties. The centipede’s many feet do not harm one another because their use is appropriate. Stone is hard, angelica is fragrant—employing each according to their abilities, the worthy become bright and the foolish exert their strength, yet success is one and the same.

Those that bloom again do not bear fruit; those that blossom too early do not need frost to fall.
The old commentary states: Those that bloom again do not bear fruit; when yang reaches its extreme, it naturally withers.

---

chunks.original_text: 污其准粉其颡 旧注准鼻也鼻有污而粉其颡犹手有疾而治其足事非常也 腐鼠在阼烧薫于堂入水而憎濡怀臭而求芳虽善者不能为工 旧注腐鼠犹奸佞也言君昵近佞人而求国之治犹入水致溺挟臭求芳薫鼠烧堂其祸不小也 冬氷可折夏木可结时难得而易失 旧注光阴可惜时命难遭喻君子俟时而动不可失之也 木方盛终日采之而复生秋风下霜一夕而零 旧注言人建功成业不可后时 质的张而矢射集林木茂而斧斤入非或召之也形势之所致 旧注不祈用而翦伐至自然之势 乳犬之噬虎伏鸡之搏狸恩之所加不量其力 旧注顾恩育者所以不觉忘生 夫待利而登溺者必将以利溺人矣【案必将以利溺人矣明刋本人字作之字】舟能浮能沈愚者不知足焉 旧注舟因水而浮亦能溺之人逢利而生亦能溺之唯审止足之分庶免沈溺之祸 骥驱之不进引之不止人君不以求道理 旧注民疲已极君敛无厌骥困更驱难规远路缵义时难得而易失民易困而难苏故物再生者实不逮获华太早者落不待霜时不顺也的张而矢集林茂而斧入势之所致乳犬噬虎伏鸡搏狸情之所使舟腐而载则沈骥疲而驱则毙民其可重困乎 水虽平必有波衡虽正必有差尺虽齐必有危非规矩不能定方员非准绳无以正曲直用规矩者亦有规矩之心 旧注上立平正之法下生乖越之分者是由波生平水差起正衡兆乎好憎迹生祸乱非君上无法制而臣下失其规矩者也 太山之高倍而不见秋毫之末视之可察 旧注所向正秋毫虽小可察所行背太山虽大不可见也 竹木有火不钻不熏土中有水不掘不出 旧注火藏于木水藏于土不钻不掘必不能出道在于人不学不知 矢之疾不过二里跬步不休跛鳖千里累块不止丘山从成 旧注凡为学者非贵疾于初心所美久于其道则千里可至丘山必成也 临河欲鱼不若归而织网 旧注河之有鱼取之在网人之有道取之在心 弓先调而后求劲马先顺而后求良人先信而后求能旧注明此三者之由可察万机之要也 巧冶不能消木良匠不能斫冰物有不可如之何君子不留意 旧注非可治之物不能成其器虽有良匠无所施其工非可导之人不能回其操虽有圣人无由谕其意也 使人无渡河可使河无波不可 旧注言河必有波世必有祸使人不犯祸则易使河无波即难 无辜不辜【案明刋本无辜不辜作无曰不辜】甑终不堕井矣 旧注辜罪也言人所获戾非谓无辜甑若不堕井安得无由矣 缵义水平不能无波衡正不能无差心其可不慎诸君子之礼义廉耻犹匠石之规矩准绳也弓先调而后求劲马先顺而后求良人不先之以信能者其可致乎故君子为其所可为而不为其所无奈何 刺我行者欲我交呰我货者欲我市 旧注欲动其中见形于外
chunks.translated_text:
If one soils the nose and powders the forehead—this is like treating the foot when the hand is afflicted, a most irregular affair. A rotten rat lies in the hall, yet one burns incense within—entering water yet hating to be wet, holding stench yet seeking fragrance: even the most skilled cannot craft success from this.

Winter ice may be broken, summer trees may be bound; opportunity is hard to obtain yet easy to lose. The old commentary states: Time is precious, fate is rare—this illustrates how the noble person awaits the moment to act, for it must not be lost.

A tree in full vigor, though felled all day, will regrow; yet when autumn winds bring frost, it withers in a single night. This speaks of building merit and accomplishing deeds—one cannot delay the hour.

The target is set and arrows strike; the forest is lush and axes enter—not by any summons, but by the force of circumstance. The old commentary states: Without seeking its use, the felling comes—this is the natural course.

A nursing dog will bite a tiger; a brooding hen will strike a fox—where favor is bestowed, strength is not measured. The old commentary states: It is the care of nurture that makes them forget their lives.

Those who climb for profit and drown will surely drown others for profit. A boat can float, can sink—the fool does not know moderation. The old commentary states: A boat floats by water yet can also drown; a person thrives by profit yet can also drown. Only by discerning the measure of sufficiency can one avoid the calamity of sinking.

A steed, though driven, does not advance; though pulled, does not stop—the ruler does not seek the Dao in this. The old commentary states: When the people are utterly exhausted and the ruler’s exactions know no limit, driving a weary steed further makes distant roads impossible to govern. Opportunity is hard to obtain yet easy to lose; the people are easily wearied yet hard to revive. Thus, what blooms again bears no fruit; what blossoms too early falls without waiting for frost—this is when the time is not favorable. The target is set and arrows strike; the forest is lush and axes enter—this is the force of circumstance. A nursing dog bites a tiger; a brooding hen strikes a fox—this is the impulse of affection. A rotten boat, if loaded, will sink; a weary steed, if driven, will perish—how can the people bear further hardship?

Though water is level, it must have waves; though a balance is true, it must have discrepancy; though a measure is even, it must have danger. Without compass and square, one cannot determine circle and square; without level and plumb, one cannot correct crooked and straight. Those who use compass and square must also have the mind of compass and square. The old commentary states: When the ruler establishes impartial laws yet the people generate discord, this is like waves arising from level water, discrepancy from a true balance—traces of favor and resentment give rise to calamity and chaos. This is not because the ruler lacks laws, but because ministers lose their compass and square.

Mount Tai’s height, though doubled, cannot be seen; the tip of an autumn hair, though small, can be discerned when viewed directly. The old commentary states: When one’s aim is true, even the tip of an autumn hair, though small, can be discerned; when one’s conduct is contrary, even Mount Tai, though vast, cannot be seen.

Bamboo and wood contain fire, yet without drilling, no smoke arises; earth contains water, yet without digging, none emerges. The old commentary states: Fire is hidden in wood, water in earth—without drilling or digging, they cannot emerge. The Dao resides in people, yet without study, it is not known.

An arrow’s speed does not exceed two li; yet with half-steps unceasing, a lame turtle travels a thousand li. Piling clods without rest, mountains and hills form. The old commentary states: In all learning, one must not prize swiftness at the outset; what matters is long devotion to the Way—then a thousand li may be reached, mountains and hills surely formed.

To stand by the river wishing for fish is not as good as returning to weave a net. The old commentary states: Fish in the river are caught by nets; the Dao in people is grasped by the mind.

First tune the bow, then seek strength; first tame the horse, then seek excellence; first establish trust, then seek ability. The old commentary states: From these three examples, one may discern the essentials of all affairs.

A skilled smith cannot melt wood; a master craftsman cannot carve ice—there are things that cannot be forced. The noble person does not dwell on them. The old commentary states: Things that cannot be worked cannot become vessels; though a master craftsman exists, his skill has no application. People who cannot be guided cannot be turned from their ways; though a sage exists, there is no way to convey his intent.

One may command a person not to cross the river, but one cannot command the river to have no waves. The old commentary states: A river must have waves; the world must have misfortune. To prevent people from encountering misfortune is easy; to make a river have no waves is difficult.

If guiltless, the pot will not fall into the well. The old commentary states: *Gu* means fault. What misfortune one incurs is not without cause—if the pot did not fall into the well, how could there be no reason?

The old commentary states: Level water cannot be without waves; a true balance cannot be without discrepancy—how can the mind not be cautious? The rites, righteousness, integrity, and shame of the noble person are like the compass, square, level, and plumb of the craftsman. First tune the bow, then seek strength; first tame the horse, then seek excellence. Without first establishing trust, can ability be attained? Thus, the noble person does what can be done and does not do what is beyond remedy.

Those who criticize my conduct wish for my friendship; those who covet my goods wish to trade with me. The old commentary states: They seek to move the inner, and it appears in the outer.

chunks.original_text: 行一棋不足以见知弹一不足以为悲 旧注一事裁通未能尽理一始张何足称妙 今有一炭然掇之烂指【案明刋本指字下有相近也三字】万石俱熏去之十步而不死同气者而异积【案明刋本作同气而异积也】 有荣华者必有愁悴 旧注荣枯迭兴哀乐相反 上有罗纨下必有麻 旧注浮沸反君上骄侈以轻绮罗下民冻馁不周于衣食为人君可不察焉 木大者根瞿【音衢】山高者基扶 旧注君以民为本高以下为基 缵义苦语利行苦药利病刺我行者欲我交君子循义也呰我货者欲我市小人狥利也人之福不可过服不必侈木大者根瞿山高者基扶民富则国昌矣 老子曰鼓不藏声故能有声镜不没形故能有形旧注鼓不藏声镜不藏形故能有声有形也 金石有声不动不鸣管箫有音不吹无声 旧注金石箫管不能自鸣皆因吹击乃能有声由人皆禀道德不学终不得成者也 是以圣人内藏不为物唱事来而制物至而应 旧注圣人言不妄发事不虚应 天行不已终而复始故能长久轮复其所转故能致远旧注天行者神而莫测运乎无穷 天行一不差故无过矣天气下地气上阴阳交通万物齐同 旧注天行一而无差君守政而无失故得天地交畅庶物咸遂君臣说睦上下康宁也 君子用事小人消亡天地之道也 旧注去邪任贤合于天地之道也 天气不下地气不上阴阳不通万物不昌小人得势君子消亡五谷不殖道德内藏 旧注天地之气不交阴阳之气不通由世主道德不用奸佞并行小人居位君子在野使万物不昌而五谷不成 天之道裒多益寡地之道损高益下 旧注天地之道【案此下当有阙文无别本可校附识于此】 神之道骄溢与下 旧注制骄溢之性与谦下之人 人之道多者不与 旧注不増有者 圣人之道卑而莫能上也 旧注终不为上故人尊也 缵义心不藏物故能应物鼓不藏声故能应声不扣而鸣则为怪矣是以圣人内藏不为物唱应之而已天地交通万物齐同此明良会遇而君子用事之时也一或反此则是小人得势之日矣惟圣人居高听卑而不自满无以上之 天明日明而后能照四方君明臣明域中乃安域有四明乃能长久明其施明者明其化也 旧注四明既备万姓俱化 天道为文 旧注日月星辰 地道为理 旧注山泽江海 一为之和 旧注融乎冲气 时为之使 旧注应而不差
