A single move in chess is insufficient to reveal one’s understanding; a single pluck of the zither is insufficient to express sorrow. The old commentary states: Mastery of one matter does not yet encompass the full principle; the first strum of a zither cannot yet be called exquisite.

Now, if a single burning coal is picked up, it scorches the fingers—yet if a myriad tons of coal are ignited, the smoke pervades all, and even at ten paces away, one does not die. Those of the same qi may differ in accumulation. Where there is flourishing splendor, there must also be sorrow and withering. The old commentary states: Prosperity and decay alternate; joy and grief oppose each other.

Above, there are silken gauze and fine fabrics; below, there must be coarse hemp and rags. The old commentary states: ** (pronounced *fúfèi*): When the ruler above is extravagant and frivolous, indulging in fine silks, the people below suffer from cold and hunger, lacking adequate clothing and food. How can a ruler fail to examine this?

The greater the tree, the deeper its roots; the higher the mountain, the broader its base. The old commentary states: The ruler takes the people as the root, the lowly as the foundation.

The *Zuan Yi* states: Bitter words benefit conduct; bitter medicine benefits illness. Those who criticize my conduct wish for my friendship—this is the noble person following righteousness. Those who covet my goods wish to trade with me—this is the petty person pursuing profit. A person’s good fortune cannot be overindulged; excess is unnecessary. The greater the tree, the deeper its roots; the higher the mountain, the broader its base. When the people are prosperous, the state flourishes.

Laozi said: The drum does not conceal sound, thus it can produce sound; the mirror does not obscure form, thus it can reflect form. The old commentary states: The drum does not conceal sound, the mirror does not conceal form—thus they can produce sound and reflect form.

Metal and stone have voices, yet if not struck, they do not ring; pipes and flutes have tones, yet if not blown, they make no sound. The old commentary states: Metal, stone, flutes, and pipes cannot sound on their own; only when struck or blown do they produce sound. This is like people: all receive the Dao and virtue, yet without learning, they never attain completion.

Thus, the sage conceals within and does not initiate; when affairs come, he governs them; when things arrive, he responds. The old commentary states: The sage does not speak recklessly; his actions are never empty responses.

The Way of Heaven moves without cease, ending and then beginning again—thus it endures long. The wheel returns to its turning—thus it travels far. The old commentary states: The movement of Heaven is divine and unfathomable, operating without end.

The movement of Heaven does not err, thus it is without fault. Heaven’s qi descends, earth’s qi ascends; yin and yang interact, and the myriad things are harmonized as one. The old commentary states: Heaven’s movement is singular and without error; the ruler governs with flawless governance—thus Heaven and Earth interact smoothly, all things flourish, ruler and minister are joyful, above and below are at peace.

When the noble person is employed, the petty person vanishes—this is the Way of Heaven and Earth. The old commentary states: Removing the wicked and appointing the worthy accords with the Way of Heaven and Earth.

When Heaven’s qi does not descend and earth’s qi does not ascend, yin and yang do not interact, and the myriad things do not prosper. When the petty person gains power and the noble person vanishes, the five grains do not grow, and the Dao and virtue are concealed within. The old commentary states: When the qi of Heaven and Earth do not interact and the qi of yin and yang do not communicate, it is because the ruler does not employ the Dao and virtue, allowing treacherous and flattering petty persons to hold office while the noble person remains in obscurity—causing the myriad things to fail and the five grains not to grow.

The Way of Heaven reduces the excessive to benefit the deficient; the Way of Earth diminishes the high to supplement the low. The old commentary states: The Way of Heaven and Earth... *[Note: The text here appears to have a lacuna; no alternate version is available for collation.]*

The Way of spirits restrains arrogance and aligns with the humble. The old commentary states: It curbs the nature of arrogance and associates with those who are modest.

The Way of humans does not give to those who already have much. The old commentary states: It does not increase those who are already abundant.

The Way of the sage is lowly, yet none can surpass it. The old commentary states: It never seeks to be above, thus people honor it.

The *Zuan Yi* states: The mind does not conceal things, thus it can respond to them; the drum does not conceal sound, thus it can respond to being struck. If it rings without being struck, it is monstrous. Thus, the sage conceals within and does not initiate—he merely responds. When Heaven and Earth interact, the myriad things are harmonized as one. This illustrates the time when worthy encounters and the noble person is employed. If this is reversed, it is the day when the petty person gains power.

Only the sage, though in high position, listens to the lowly and does not become complacent, never placing himself above. When the sun is bright, it can illuminate the four directions; when the ruler is enlightened, the minister is enlightened, and the realm is at peace. When the realm has these four enlightened ones, it can endure long. To be enlightened in governance is to be enlightened in transformation. The old commentary states: When the four enlightened ones are complete, all the people are transformed.

The Way of Heaven creates patterns. The old commentary states: The sun, moon, stars, and constellations.

The Way of Earth establishes order. The old commentary states: The mountains, marshes, rivers, and seas.

One harmonizes them. The old commentary states: Fusing with the harmonious qi.

Timing commands them. The old commentary states: Responding without error.

chunks.original_text: 以成万物命之曰道 旧注生畜万物不自为宰故名曰道者也 大道坦坦去身不远修之于身其德乃真修之于物其德不绝 旧注内修其身谓之真外育于物谓之德 天覆万物施其德而养之与而不取故精神归焉与而不取者上德也是以有德高莫高于天也下莫下于泽也天高泽下圣人法之尊卑有叙天下定矣 旧注卑高以陈贵贱位矣 地载万物而长之与而取之故骨骸归焉与而取者下德也下德不失德是以无德 旧注不取者谓天生万物但畜养之不取其材故精神归于上终有德而取者谓地生万物虽成熟之而复其质故骨骸归于下是为无德也 地承天故定宁地定宁万物形地广厚万物众定宁无不载广厚无不容地势深厚水泉入聚地道方广故能久长圣人法之德无不容 旧注言天地相承以致广厚君臣相信自致治和缵义君天道臣地道天尊地卑君臣之分定矣君明臣明照于四方岂非尧之光宅天下百姓昭明者乎故法天效地以成万物者道也养之与之而不取者上德也与而取之德斯下矣 阴难阳万物昌阳伏阴万物湛物昌无不赡也物湛无不乐也物乐无不治矣【案明刋本物乐无不治矣句物乐二字下多一则字】阴害物阳自屈阴进阳退小人得势君子避害天道然也旧注阳制于阴则天下和治臣胜于君则小人在位也 阳气动万物缓而得其所是以圣人顺阳道夫顺物者物亦顺之逆物者物亦逆之故不失物之情性洿【音乌】泽盈万物节成洿泽枯万物节荂【音敷】故雨泽不行天下亡阳上亦复下【案明刋本作阳上而复下】故为万物主不长有故能终而复始故能长久能长久故为天下母 旧注圣人顺天之道无为长久逆物之情有位莫守 阳气蓄而复能施阴气积而复能化未有不蓄积而能化者也【案明刋本而能化者也而字下多一后字】故圣人慎所积 旧注积德来庆积恶致亡 阳灭阴万物肥阴灭阳万物衰故王公尚阳道则万物昌尚阴道则天下亡 旧注阳者正也生也故物肥肥者即昌阴者邪也死也故物衰衰者即亡 阳不下阴则万物不成君不下臣德化不行故君下臣则聪明不下臣则暗聋 旧注君非至圣不能下臣臣非至贤不能弼君虞舜屈伯成文王师尚父可谓聪明 缵义阳生阴杀故君子好生小人好杀也王公尚阳道则万物昌尚阴道则天下亡阳贵下阴故君下臣则聪明而国理不下臣则暗聋而德化不行 日出于地万物蕃息王公居民上以明道德日入于地万物休息小人居民上万物逃匿 旧注谓阳不下阴则万物不昌君不下臣则万物藏也 雷之动也万物启雨之润也万物解大人施行有似于此阴阳之动有常节大人之动不极物 旧注大人之威也如春之雷其发令也如暄之风皆声和气顺故不极物 雷动于地万物缓风揺树草木散大人去恶就善民不远徙民有去就也去尤甚就少逾【案民有去就也句明刋本民字上多一故字】 旧注且大人有善百姓交归若太王之去邠人何远哉 风不动火不出大人不出【案明刋夲无大人不出句】大人不言小人无述火之出也必待薪大人之言必有信有信而真何往不成 旧注火出而薪传言发而信行故知大人之言其行也往而不追其信也有若四时 河水深壤在山丘陵高下入渊阳气盛变为阴阴气盛变为阳故欲不可盈乐不可极 旧注天之道抑高举下唯节欲全和以顺天理不使至极 忿无恶言怒无作色是谓计得 旧注虽忿怒未忘而恶言悖色未形于外是计得于中镇之以道也 火上炎水下流圣人之道以相求偯【音矣】阳天下和同偯阴天下溺沈【案明刋夲以相求句下有圣入二字疑衍】

The Dao gives life to the myriad things and is thus named. The old commentary states: It nurtures and sustains the myriad things without acting as their master, hence it is called the Dao.

The Great Dao is level and broad, never far from the self. Cultivate it within the self, and its virtue becomes true; cultivate it in things, and its virtue never ceases. The old commentary states: Cultivating it within is called truth; nurturing it externally is called virtue.

Heaven covers the myriad things, bestowing its virtue to nourish them, giving without taking—this is the highest virtue. Thus, in virtue, none is higher than Heaven, none lower than the marsh. Heaven is high, the marsh low; the sage emulates this, establishing hierarchy and order, and the world is settled. The old commentary states: High and low are arrayed, noble and base find their places.

Earth bears the myriad things and makes them grow, giving and taking—thus bones and skeletons return to it. Giving and taking is the lesser virtue; the lesser virtue does not lose virtue, yet it is called "without virtue." The old commentary states: Not taking means Heaven gives life to the myriad things, merely nurturing them without claiming their substance, so the spirit returns above. Taking means Earth, though it matures the myriad things, reclaims their essence, so bones and skeletons return below—this is called "without virtue."

Earth follows Heaven, thus it is settled and at peace. When Earth is settled and at peace, the forms of the myriad things take shape. Earth is vast and thick, and the myriad things are numerous. Settled and at peace, there is nothing it does not bear; vast and thick, there is nothing it does not contain. Earth’s depth and thickness gather water and springs; its breadth and expanse endure long. The sage emulates this, and his virtue admits all. The old commentary states: Heaven and Earth follow one another to achieve vastness and thickness; ruler and minister trust one another to achieve governance and harmony. The ruler embodies the Way of Heaven, the minister the Way of Earth. Heaven is noble, Earth base—the distinction between ruler and minister is fixed. When the ruler is enlightened and the minister enlightened, they illuminate the four directions—is this not like Yao’s radiance filling the world, where the hundred clans are bright? Thus, to emulate Heaven and Earth in completing the myriad things is the Dao. Nurturing them, giving without taking, is the highest virtue; giving and taking, virtue becomes lesser.

Yin submits to yang, and the myriad things flourish; yang submits to yin, and the myriad things perish. When things flourish, none lacks abundance; when they perish, none lacks joy. When things are joyful, none is ungoverned. [Note in the Ming printed edition: After "things are joyful," there is an additional "then."]

Yin harms things, yang yields of itself; yin advances, yang retreats. When petty men gain power, the noble withdraw to avoid harm—this is the Way of Heaven. The old commentary states: When yang is constrained by yin, the world is harmonious and well-governed; when ministers overpower the ruler, petty men hold office.

Yang qi moves, and the myriad things are at ease, each in its place. Thus, the sage follows the yang Way. Those who follow things, things follow them; those who oppose things, things oppose them. Thus, one does not lose the nature and feelings of things. When marshes are full, the myriad things mature; when marshes dry, the myriad things wither. Thus, when rain and moisture do not flow, the world perishes. Yang rises and then returns below—thus it is the master of the myriad things, not long abiding, yet able to end and begin anew, thus enduring long. Enduring long, it becomes the mother of the world. The old commentary states: The sage follows Heaven’s Way, acting without striving, thus enduring long; opposing the feelings of things, even with position, none can preserve it.

Yang qi accumulates and then can bestow; yin qi gathers and then can transform. There has never been one who, without accumulation, could transform. Thus, the sage is cautious in what he accumulates. The old commentary states: Accumulating virtue brings blessings; accumulating evil leads to ruin.

When yang extinguishes yin, the myriad things grow fat; when yin extinguishes yang, the myriad things decline. Thus, kings and lords esteem the yang Way, and the myriad things flourish; they esteem the yin Way, and the world perishes. The old commentary states: Yang is uprightness and life, thus things grow fat—fat means flourishing. Yin is depravity and death, thus things decline—decline means perishing.

If yang does not descend to yin, the myriad things do not mature; if the ruler does not descend to the minister, virtuous transformation does not spread. Thus, when the ruler descends to the minister, wisdom and clarity prevail; when he does not descend, darkness and deafness ensue. The old commentary states: Unless the ruler is supremely sagely, he cannot descend to the minister; unless the minister is supremely worthy, he cannot assist the ruler. Yu Shun humbled himself before Bo Cheng; King Wen treated Jiang Shang as his teacher—these may be called wise and clear.

Continuing the thread: yang gives life, yin kills. Thus, the noble man cherishes life, the petty man delights in killing. Kings and lords esteem the yang Way, and the myriad things flourish; they esteem the yin Way, and the world perishes. Yang values descending, yin does not. Thus, when the ruler descends to the minister, wisdom and clarity prevail, and the state is well-governed; when he does not descend, darkness and deafness ensue, and virtuous transformation does not spread.

The sun rises from the earth, and the myriad things thrive; kings and lords stand above the people, illuminating the Dao and its virtue. The sun sets into the earth, and the myriad things rest; petty men stand above the people, and the myriad things flee and hide. The old commentary states: This means when yang does not descend to yin, the myriad things do not flourish; when the ruler does not descend to the minister, the myriad things conceal themselves.

When thunder moves, the myriad things awaken; when rain moistens, the myriad things are released. The conduct of great men resembles this. The movement of yin and yang has constant measure; the actions of great men do not exceed things. The old commentary states: The majesty of great men is like spring thunder; their commands are like the warm wind—all is harmonious in sound and qi, thus they do not exceed things.

Thunder moves upon the earth, and the myriad things are at ease; wind sways the trees, and grasses and trees scatter. Great men remove evil and pursue goodness, and the people do not wander far. The people have departures and arrivals—departing from the extreme, arriving at the lesser. [Note in the Ming printed edition: Before "the people have departures and arrivals," there is an additional "thus."] The old commentary states: Moreover, when great men have goodness, the hundred clans gather to them. Like King Tai leaving Bin—how far did the people go?

When wind does not move, fire does not emerge; when great men do not emerge, petty men have nothing to transmit. Fire emerges only when there is fuel; the words of great men must be trustworthy. With trust and truth, what cannot be accomplished? The old commentary states: Fire emerges and spreads through fuel; words are issued and trust is established. Thus, the words of great men proceed without retreating, their trust like the four seasons.

The Yellow River’s waters are deep, its banks lie in the mountains; hills and mounds rise and fall into the abyss. Yang qi flourishes and transforms into yin; yin qi flourishes and transforms into yang. Thus, desire must not be filled, joy must not be extreme. The old commentary states: The Way of Heaven humbles the high and raises the low. Only by moderating desires and preserving harmony can one follow Heaven’s principle, not allowing things to reach extremity.

Anger without harsh words, wrath without fierce expression—this is called calculated gain. The old commentary states: Though angry, one does not forget; though enraged, harsh words and fierce expressions do not appear externally—this is calculated gain within, governed by the Dao.

Fire flames upward, water flows downward; the sage’s Way seeks harmony through yielding. When yang prevails, the world is harmonious and united; when yin prevails, the world is submerged and sunk. [Note in the Ming printed edition: After "seeks harmony," there are two characters, "圣入," likely superfluous.]

chunks.original_text: 旧注偯阳者亲忠贤故和同偯阴者亲奸佞故沈溺缵义天之日其人之君乎日出于地王公居民上万物蕃息日入于地小人居民上万物逃匿阴阳之动有常节故岁不乱时大人之动不极物故民不远徙物极则变欲不可盈阴阳天也治乱则关乎人 老子曰积薄成厚积卑成高君子日汲汲以成辉【音晖】小人日快快以至辱 旧注君子勤身以修道日益晖光小人乘闲以快意终至困辱 其消息也虽未能见故见善如不及宿不善如不祥苟向善虽过无怨苟不向善虽忠来恶故怨人不如自怨勉求诸人不如求诸已声自召也自求也名自命也人自官也无非已者操锐以刺操刃以击何怨于人故君子慎其微 旧注慎微言不在大也苟向善则福不因人勉求诸已苟不向善则祸归于身何怨于人不善犹操刃自割积火自烧又谁咎之者也 万物负阴而抱阳冲气以为和和居中央是以木实生于心草实生于荚卵胎生于中央不卵不胎生而须时旧注物殊异言其所生皆自中和而成质其非胎卵而因变化所为者即须时而有也 地平则水不流轻重均则衡不倾 旧注地平则水无奔驰之势衡均则物无轻重之偏 物之生化也有感以然 旧注万物之生各有所感非徒然也 缵义阴阳感而成中和故万物生君臣合而得中道故万姓宁是以君子和其心志日汲汲以成晖小人汨其天和日快快以至辱故君子慎微正诸心而自求诸已我不怨人人亦无怨焉 老子曰山致其高而云雨起焉水致其深而蛟龙生焉君子致其道而德泽流焉夫有阴德者必有阳报有行者必有昭名 旧注山之灵者必降云雨道之高者必施德泽未有不先行其事而后致其报 树黍者不获稷树怨者无报德 旧注树黍获稷以怨报德未之有也 缵义为善而人不知谓之至善为恶而人不知谓之至恶山藏云而成雨露泽藏水而生蛟龙君子怀其道而泽流于世俗有阴德者必有阳报天佑之也有行者必有昭名人推之也惟有天德者知之 钦定四库全书 文子缵义卷七　　　　　宋　杜道坚　撰
chunks.translated_text:
The old commentary states: When yang prevails, it draws near to the loyal and worthy, thus the world is harmonious and united; when yin prevails, it draws near to the treacherous and sycophantic, thus the world is submerged and sunk. To continue the analogy: Heaven’s sun—is it not the ruler of men? When the sun rises from the earth, dukes and lords govern above the people, and the myriad things flourish; when the sun sets into the earth, petty men govern above the people, and the myriad things flee and hide. The movement of yin and yang has its constant measure, thus the year does not disorder the seasons; the movement of the great person does not reach extremity in things, thus the people do not wander far. When things reach extremity, they transform. Desires must not be filled to the brim—yin and yang are of Heaven, but order and chaos depend on man.

Laozi said: "Accumulating thinness makes thickness; accumulating lowness makes height." The noble person daily strives to achieve radiance; the petty person daily indulges to reach disgrace. The old commentary states: The noble person diligently cultivates the Dao, daily increasing in brilliance; the petty person seizes leisure to gratify desires, ultimately reaching distress and disgrace. Though its waxing and waning may not yet be visible, one sees goodness as if never sufficient, and lodges evil as if it were an ill omen. If one inclines toward goodness, though there be faults, there is no resentment; if one does not incline toward goodness, though there be loyalty, evil comes. Thus, resenting others is not as good as resenting oneself; exhorting others is not as good as seeking within. Sound summons itself; harmony seeks itself; reputation commands itself; office is self-assumed. There is nothing that is not oneself. Wielding a sharp point to stab, grasping a blade to strike—why resent others? Therefore, the noble person is cautious in the subtle.

The old commentary states: To be cautious in the subtle is not a matter of greatness. If one inclines toward goodness, then blessing does not depend on others; if one exhorts oneself, then if one does not incline toward goodness, calamity returns to oneself—why resent others? Evil is like grasping a blade to cut oneself; accumulating fire to burn oneself—who else can one blame? The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang, using qi to achieve harmony. Harmony resides in the center, thus the fruit of trees grows from the heart, the seed of grasses grows from the pod, and eggs and wombs generate from the center. Those that are neither egg nor womb but require time to be born—

The old commentary states: Things differ in kind, but all speak of what is generated as arising from central harmony and forming substance. Those that are neither womb nor egg but depend on transformation must await their time to come into being.

When the earth is level, water does not flow; when light and heavy are balanced, the scale does not tilt. The old commentary states: When the earth is level, water has no rushing force; when the scale is balanced, things have no bias of light or heavy.

The generation and transformation of things have their causes. The old commentary states: The birth of the myriad things each has its stimulus, not arising without reason. To continue the analogy: Yin and yang stimulate each other to form central harmony, thus the myriad things are born; ruler and minister unite to attain the central Dao, thus the myriad people are at peace. Therefore, the noble person harmonizes his heart and will, daily striving to achieve radiance; the petty person disrupts his natural harmony, daily indulging to reach disgrace. Thus, the noble person is cautious in the subtle, rectifies his heart, and seeks within himself. I do not resent others, and others harbor no resentment.

Laozi said: "When mountains reach their height, clouds and rain arise; when waters reach their depth, dragons are born; when the noble person attains the Dao, virtue and grace flow forth. Those who possess hidden virtue will surely receive manifest reward; those who have concealed conduct will surely gain illustrious renown." The old commentary states: The numinous mountains must send down clouds and rain; the lofty Dao must bestow virtue and grace. There has never been one who did not first perform the deed and later receive the reward.

Those who plant millet do not reap millet; those who plant resentment receive no return of virtue. The old commentary states: To plant millet and reap millet, or to repay virtue with resentment—such has never been.

To continue the analogy: Doing good without others knowing is called utmost goodness; doing evil without others knowing is called utmost evil. Mountains conceal clouds and form rain and dew; abysses conceal water and generate dragons; the noble person cherishes the Dao, and grace flows to the world. Those who possess hidden virtue will surely receive manifest reward—Heaven aids them; those who have concealed conduct will surely gain illustrious renown—people esteem them. Only those who possess Heavenly virtue know this.
chunks.overlap_context:
The old commentary states: Though angry, one does not forget; though enraged, harsh words and fierce expressions do not appear externally—this is calculated gain within, governed by the Dao.

Fire flames upward, water flows downward; the sage’s Way seeks harmony through yielding. When yang prevails, the world is harmonious and united; when yin prevails, the world is submerged and sunk. [Note in the Ming printed edition: After "seeks harmony," there are two characters, "圣入," likely superfluous.]

chunks.original_text: 微明篇 旧注视于无形之形听于无声之声故曰微明 老子曰道可以弱可以强可以柔可以刚可以阴可以阳可以幽可以明可以包裹天地可以应待无方知之浅不知之深知之外不知之内知之粗不知之精知之乃不知不知乃知之孰知知之为不知不知之为知乎夫道不可闻闻而非也道不可见见而非也道不可言言而非也孰知形之不形者乎故天下皆知善之为善也斯不善矣知者不言言者不知 缵义微明者其道乎视不以目听不以耳得之天而着之心故能包裹天地应待无方不可以智力求惟知不知为不为言不言则得之矣 文子问曰人可以微言乎老子曰何为不可惟知言之谓乎夫知言之谓者不以言言也争鱼者濡逐兽者趋非乐之也故至言去言至为去为浅知之人所争者末矣夫言有宗事有君夫唯无知是以不吾知 缵义道不可言可言即物言固非道非言不明文子问人可以微言乎老子语以唯知言为可则是言而不言不言而言者矣争鱼逐兽是不知言者执于言而着于物则所争者末矣安得去言去为之人而与之言哉 文子问曰为国亦有法乎老子曰今夫挽车者前呼邪许【按明刋本邪许作邪轷轷火乎切】后亦应之此挽车劝力之歌也虽郑卫胡楚之音不若此之义也治国有礼不在文辩法令滋彰盗贼多有 缵义有国家者犹天地也天不言而四时行地不语而百物生文子问为国之法老子语以挽车之歌前呼后应亦犹圣人先天弗违后天奉时之意治国有礼初不在于文华之辩不知治体而滋彰其法令者适以为盗法贼民之资 老子曰道无正而可以为正譬若山林而可以为材材不及山林山林不及云雨云雨不及阴阳阴阳不及和和不及道道者所谓无状之状无物之象也无达其意天地之间可陶冶而变化也 缵义道无正形物随而形观山林变而至于云雨阴阳之和则知凡天地间之无形无象者皆可陶冶而变化道其神矣夫 老子曰圣人立教施政必察其终始见其造恩故民知书而德衰知数而仁衰知劵契而信衰知机械而实衰瑟不鸣于己而二十五各以其声应轴不运于己而三十幅各以其力旋有缓急然后能成曲车有劳佚然后能致远使有声者乃无声也【按明刋本乃无声也作乃无声者也】使有转者乃无转也上下异道易治即乱位高而道大者从事大而道小者凶小德害义小善害道小辩害治苛峭伤德大正不险故民易导至治优防故下不贼至忠复素故民无伪匿 缵义圣人立教施政弗获已也必察其始终行其所无事而已知书数劵契机械则是有心于事德仁信实衰矣君借臣以为治犹瑟之有声辐之致远执要用大则无不治之世矣 老子曰相坐之法立即百姓怨减爵之令张即功臣叛故察于刀笔之迹者不知治乱之本习于行陈之事者不知庙战之权圣人见福于重关之内【按明刋本见福作先福当以此本正其误】虑患于防防之外愚者惑于小利而忘大害故事有利于小而害于大得于此而忘于彼故仁莫大于爱人智莫大于知人爱人即无怨刑知人则无乱政缵义治不可以多事法不可以数变事多变数则百姓怨功臣叛上有以召之矣治乱之本庙战之权圣人鉴于无形之表是必有先见之明也 老子曰江河之大溢不过三日飘风暴雨日中不出须臾止德无所积而不忧者亡其及也夫忧者所以昌也喜者所以亡也故善者以弱为强转祸为福道冲而用之又不满也 缵义国之苛政横出犹江河之大溢风雨之暴作曾不少久亡其及矣唯忧无德而知变者尚可转祸为福以弱为强其不可自满也明矣
chunks.translated_text:
**The Subtle Illumination**

The old commentary states: To perceive the formless form, to hear the soundless sound—hence it is called "subtle illumination." Laozi said: The Dao may be weak, may be strong; may be yielding, may be firm; may be yin, may be yang; may be obscure, may be luminous. It can envelop Heaven and Earth, respond to all directions without limit. What is known of it is shallow; what is unknown, deep. What is perceived of it lies without; what is unperceived, within. What is grasped of it is coarse; what is ungrasped, refined. To know it is not to know; not to know is to know. Who understands that knowing is not knowing, and not knowing is knowing?

The Dao cannot be heard—what is heard is not it. The Dao cannot be seen—what is seen is not it. The Dao cannot be spoken—what is spoken is not it. Who comprehends the formless form?

Thus, when all under Heaven know goodness as goodness, this is already not goodness. The wise do not speak; those who speak are not wise.

The *Zuan Yi* states: "Subtle illumination" is the Dao. To see without the eyes, to hear without the ears—it is attained in Heaven and inscribed in the heart. Thus it can envelop Heaven and Earth, respond to all directions without limit. It cannot be sought through cunning or force; only by knowing not-knowing, acting not-acting, speaking not-speaking can it be grasped.

Wenzi asked: Can one speak subtly?
Laozi replied: Why not? Only those who know speech do not speak. Those who contend for fish become drenched; those who chase beasts hasten—yet they do not delight in it. Thus, the utmost word abandons words; the utmost act abandons acts. What the shallow-minded contend over is but the trivial.

Speech has its origin; affairs have their ruler. Only the ignorant do not understand me.

The *Zuan Yi* states: The Dao cannot be spoken; if it could, it would be spoken of as a thing—yet this is not the Dao. If not spoken, it would remain obscure. When Wenzi asked whether one could speak subtly, Laozi replied that only those who know speech can do so—this is to speak without speaking, to not speak while speaking. Those who contend for fish or chase beasts do not understand speech. Clinging to words and attaching to things, what they contend over is but the trivial. How can one abandon words and acts to speak with such a person?

Wenzi asked: Is there a method for governing a state?
Laozi replied: Consider those who pull a cart: the front calls out *xiehu*, and the rear responds. This is the song that encourages their strength. Though the music of Zheng, Wei, Hu, and Chu may be fine, it does not match the meaning of this. In governing a state, propriety exists, but not in ornate debate. When laws and decrees proliferate, thieves and bandits abound.

The *Zuan Yi* states: Those who govern a state are like Heaven and Earth. Heaven does not speak, yet the four seasons proceed; Earth does not utter, yet the myriad things grow. When Wenzi asked about the method of governing a state, Laozi replied with the song of the cart-pullers—front calling, rear responding—just as the sage precedes Heaven without opposing it, follows Heaven in its seasons. Governing a state begins with propriety, not with florid debate. Those who do not understand the essence of governance and instead multiply laws and decrees merely provide thieves with tools to plunder the people.

Laozi said: The Dao has no fixed norm, yet it can serve as the norm. It is like forests and mountains, which can provide timber. Yet timber does not surpass forests and mountains; forests and mountains do not surpass clouds and rain; clouds and rain do not surpass yin and yang; yin and yang do not surpass harmony; harmony does not surpass the Dao. The Dao is what is called the formless form, the imageless image. Its meaning cannot be fully conveyed. Between Heaven and Earth, all can be molded and transformed.

The *Zuan Yi* states: The Dao has no fixed form; things take shape in accordance with it. Observing forests and mountains transforming into clouds and rain, yin and yang harmonizing—one knows that all formless and imageless things between Heaven and Earth can be molded and transformed. How wondrous is the Dao!

Laozi said: The sage establishes teachings and implements governance only after examining their beginning and end, perceiving their origin and outcome. Thus, when the people know writing, virtue declines; when they know calculation, benevolence declines; when they know contracts, trust declines; when they know machinery, sincerity declines. The zither does not sound of itself, yet its twenty-five strings each respond with their own tone. The axle does not turn of itself, yet its thirty spokes each rotate with their own force. Only when there is tension and release can music be completed; only when there is labor and rest can distant journeys be achieved. If what has sound were made soundless, if what turns were made motionless—then the high and low would follow different paths. When governance is easy, disorder arises. Those in high positions with great Dao engage in great affairs; those with small Dao meet with misfortune. Minor virtue harms righteousness; minor goodness harms the Dao; minor debate harms governance; harshness injures virtue. Great uprightness is not perilous, so the people are easily guided. Excessive defenses lead to betrayal below. Utmost loyalty returns to simplicity, so the people do not conceal or deceive.

The *Zuan Yi* states: The sage establishes teachings and implements governance out of necessity, examining their beginning and end, acting without contrivance. Knowing writing, calculation, contracts, and machinery is to act with intention—thus virtue, benevolence, trust, and sincerity decline. The ruler relies on ministers for governance, just as the zither has sound and the spokes achieve distance. Grasping the essential and employing the great—then no age will be ungoverned.

Laozi said: When laws of mutual implication are established, the people resent them. When decrees reducing ranks are issued, meritorious officials rebel. Thus, those who scrutinize the traces of brush and ink do not understand the root of order and chaos. Those practiced in military formations do not grasp the authority of temple strategy. The sage perceives fortune within the innermost gates, considers calamity beyond the outermost defenses. The foolish are deluded by small gains and forget great harm. Thus, affairs may benefit the small but harm the great; gain may be had here while loss occurs there. There is no greater benevolence than loving people; no greater wisdom than knowing people. Loving people leaves no resentment; knowing people leaves no disordered governance.

The *Zuan Yi* states: Governance cannot be overburdened with affairs; laws cannot be frequently altered. When affairs multiply and changes are frequent, the people resent them, and meritorious officials rebel—this is the ruler’s doing. The root of order and chaos, the authority of temple strategy—the sage discerns the unseen, possessing foresight.

Laozi said: The great floods of rivers and streams do not last beyond three days. Fierce winds and torrential rains do not persist past noon. Where virtue is not accumulated, there is no cause for worry—yet ruin comes swiftly. Worry brings prosperity; joy brings ruin. Thus, the good turn weakness into strength, transform misfortune into fortune. The Dao is empty yet inexhaustible in use.

The *Zuan Yi* states: A state’s harsh policies erupt like the great floods of rivers, like the sudden storms of wind and rain—yet they do not last long. Ruin comes swiftly. Only those who worry over lacking virtue and know how to change can turn misfortune into fortune, weakness into strength. That one must not be self-satisfied is clear.

chunks.original_text: 老子曰清静恬和人之性也 仪表规矩事之制也 知人之性即自养不悖知事之制则其举措不乱发一号散无竞【按明刋本无竞作无竟】总一管谓之心见本而知末执一而应万谓之术居知所以行知所之事知所乘动知所止谓之道使人高贤称誉已者心之力也 使人卑下诽谤已者心之过也 言出于口不可禁于人行发于近不可禁于远事者难成易败名者难立易废凡人皆轻小害易微事以至于大患夫祸之至也 人自生之福之来也 人自成之祸与福同门利与害同邻自非至精莫之能分是故智虑者祸福之门户也 动静者利害之枢机也 不可不慎察也 缵义天理人欲同乎一心君子小人由乎一已亦同出而异名者耶执一而应万谓之术见动而知止谓之道言出乎口行发乎心夫祸福利害有如影响自非至精孰能分之可不察诸已而慎诸心乎 老子曰人皆知治乱之机而莫知全生之具故圣人论世而为之事推事而为之谋【按明刋本推事作权事】圣人能阴能阳能柔能刚能弱能强随时动静因资而立功睹物往而知其反事一而察其变化即为之象运则为之应是以终身行之无所困故事或可言而不可行者或可行而不可言者或易为而难成者或难成而易败者所谓可行而不可言者取舍也可言而不可行者伪诈也易为而难成者事也难成而易败者名也此四者圣人之所留心也明者之所独见也 缵义时有治乱政存乎人知治乱之机而莫知全生之具者失在人而不在时也圣人随时动静察其所变终身行之而无所困当时而秉政者恶可自惰而不知全生之具耶 老子曰道者敬小微动不失时百射重戒祸乃不滋计福不及虑祸过之同日被霜蔽者不伤愚者有备与智者同功夫积爱成福积憎成祸人皆知救患莫知使患无生夫使患无生易施救于患难今人不务使患无生而务施救于患虽神人不能为谋患祸之所由来万万无方圣人深居以避患静默以待时小人不知祸福之门动而陷于刑虽曲为之备不足以全身故上士先避患而后就利先远辱而后求名故圣人常从事于无形之外而不留心于己成之内是以祸患无由至非誉不能尘垢 缵义夫道者敬小微动不失时谨初也愚者有备与智者同功人之祸患不能弭于前而求救于后者虽神人不能为谋故上士以避患远辱为先而名之与利则置之后而毋必祸患何从而至非誉何从而尘垢之哉 老子曰凡人之道心欲小志欲大智欲圆行欲方能欲多事欲少所谓心小者虑患未生戒祸慎微不敢纵其欲也 志大者【按明刋本志大者作志欲大者欲字当】兼包万国一齐殊俗是非辐辏中为之毂也 智圆者终始无端方流四远渊泉而不竭也 行方者立直而不挠素白而不污穷不易操达不肆志也 能多者文武备具动静中仪举措废置曲得其宜也 事少者秉要以偶众执约以治广处静以持躁也 故心小者禁于微也 志大者无不怀也 智圆者无不知也 行方者有不为也 能多者无不治也 事少者约所持也 故圣人之于善也 无小而不行其于过也 无微而不改行不用巫觋而神不敢先可谓至贵矣 然而战战栗栗日慎一日是以无为而一之诚也 【按明刋本诚作成误】愚人之智固已少矣 而所为之事又多故动必穷故以正教化【按明刋本正作政不知此句正字与下句邪字对则正似不当作政】其势易而必成以邪教化其势难而必败舍其易而必成从事于难而必败愚惑之所致 缵义志欲大而心欲小智欲圆而行欲方能欲多而事欲少斯六者凡人之不可不勉也志大则物无不容心小则几微必戒智圆则事无不通行方则直而不挠能多则为无不成事少则约而有守夫圣人之行不用巫觋而鬼神不敢先一之以诚而巳
chunks.translated_text:
Laozi said: Serenity and harmony are the nature of man; propriety and rules are the systems of affairs. Knowing man’s nature, one nurtures the self without transgression; knowing the systems of affairs, one’s actions are never disordered. Issuing a single command, scattering without contention—[note: the Ming printed edition reads "without end" for "without contention"]—unifying all under one guiding principle is called the heart. Seeing the root and knowing the branch, holding to the One and responding to the myriad is called technique. Abiding in knowledge to act, knowing where one goes, knowing what one relies upon in movement, knowing where one stops—this is called the Dao. Causing others to praise and esteem oneself is the power of the heart; causing others to belittle and slander oneself is the fault of the heart. Words spoken from the mouth cannot be forbidden by others; actions begun nearby cannot be forbidden from afar. Affairs are difficult to accomplish yet easy to ruin; reputation is difficult to establish yet easy to destroy. All people take lightly small harms and trivial matters, yet these lead to great calamity. When misfortune arrives, man himself gives birth to it; when fortune comes, man himself brings it to completion. Misfortune and fortune share the same gate; profit and harm dwell in the same neighborhood. Without utmost clarity, none can distinguish them. Thus, wisdom and foresight are the gate and door of misfortune and fortune; movement and stillness are the pivot and trigger of profit and harm. One cannot but examine them carefully.

The *Zuan Yi* states: Heavenly principle and human desire arise from the same heart; the noble man and the petty man emerge from the same self—yet they share a single origin but bear different names. Holding to the One and responding to the myriad is called technique; seeing movement and knowing where to stop is called the Dao. Words issue from the mouth; actions arise from the heart. Misfortune and fortune, profit and harm follow like shadows and echoes. Without utmost clarity, who can distinguish them? Can one not examine them within oneself and be cautious in the heart?

Laozi said: All know the mechanism of order and chaos yet none know the tools for preserving life. Thus, the sage assesses the world and acts accordingly, weighing affairs to devise plans—[note: the Ming printed edition reads "weighing affairs" as "weighing matters"]. The sage can be yin or yang, soft or hard, weak or strong, moving or still with the times, establishing merit by relying on resources. Observing things’ tendencies, one knows their return; attending to one affair, one examines its transformations, then models and responds accordingly. Thus, one may practice this all one’s life without encountering困. Some matters can be spoken of but not practiced; some can be practiced but not spoken of; some are easy to do yet difficult to complete; some are difficult to complete yet easy to ruin. What can be practiced but not spoken of is taking and abandoning; what can be spoken of but not practiced is deceit and falsehood. What is easy to do yet difficult to complete is affairs; what is difficult to complete yet easy to ruin is reputation. These four are what the sage attends to, what the wise alone perceive.

The *Zuan Yi* states: Times may be ordered or chaotic, but governance lies with man. Knowing the mechanism of order and chaos yet not knowing the tools for preserving life—this failure lies in man, not in the times. The sage moves or is still with the times, examining their changes, practicing this all one’s life without encountering困. How can those who hold power in their time be indolent and not know the tools for preserving life?

Laozi said: The Dao reveres the minute and subtle, never missing the moment. In archery, one is cautious of misfortune, lest it grow. Calculating fortune does not compare to considering misfortune; on the same day, those covered by frost are not harmed. The foolish, when prepared, share the same merit as the wise. Accumulating love brings fortune; accumulating hatred brings misfortune. All know how to rescue from calamity, yet none know how to prevent calamity from arising. Preventing calamity from arising is easier than rescuing from calamity. Now, people do not strive to prevent calamity from arising but strive to rescue from calamity—even a divine being could not devise a plan for this. The sources of misfortune and calamity are boundless. The sage dwells in seclusion to avoid calamity, remains silent to await the moment. The petty man, unaware of the gate of misfortune and fortune, moves and falls into punishment. Though he bends every effort to prepare, it is not enough to preserve his life. Thus, the superior man first avoids calamity, then pursues profit; first distances himself from disgrace, then seeks reputation. Therefore, the sage always attends to what lies beyond the formless and does not dwell on what is already accomplished within. Thus, misfortune has no way to arrive, and neither praise nor blame can tarnish him.

The *Zuan Yi* states: The Dao reveres the minute and subtle, never missing the moment—this is caution at the outset. The foolish, when prepared, share the same merit as the wise. Man’s misfortunes cannot be averted beforehand but are sought to be rescued afterward—even a divine being could not devise a plan for this. Thus, the superior man takes avoiding calamity and distancing disgrace as primary, placing reputation and profit afterward without insistence. How then could misfortune arrive? How could praise or blame tarnish him?

Laozi said: In the Dao of man, the heart desires smallness, the will desires greatness, wisdom desires roundness, conduct desires squareness, abilities desire multiplicity, affairs desire fewness. What is called a small heart is to consider misfortune before it arises, to be cautious of calamity and vigilant in subtleties, never indulging one’s desires. A great will—[note: the Ming printed edition reads "a great will desires" with "desires" likely an interpolation]—encompasses the myriad states, unifying disparate customs, with right and wrong converging like spokes at the hub. Round wisdom has no beginning or end, flowing to the four directions like a deep spring that never runs dry. Square conduct stands upright without bending, pure and unstained, unwavering in poverty, unrestrained in success. Multifaceted ability encompasses civil and martial, moving and still in accord with propriety, with actions and placements perfectly fitting. Few affairs mean grasping the essential to pair with the many, holding the simple to govern the broad, abiding in stillness to restrain restlessness.

Thus, a small heart forbids the minute; a great will embraces all; round wisdom knows all; square conduct refrains from all; multifaceted ability governs all; few affairs mean simplicity in what one holds. Therefore, the sage, in regard to goodness, leaves nothing small undone; in regard to faults, leaves nothing subtle uncorrected. He does not employ shamans or mediums, yet spirits dare not precede him—this may be called utmost nobility. Yet he trembles and quakes, cautious day by day, thus achieving effortless unity through sincerity—[note: the Ming printed edition mistakenly reads "sincerity" as "completion"]. The foolish man’s wisdom is already meager, yet the affairs he undertakes are many, so he inevitably falls into困. Thus, using uprightness to transform—[note: the Ming printed edition reads "governance" for "uprightness," but since it opposes "deviance" below, "uprightness" seems correct]—is easy and will surely succeed; using deviance to transform is difficult and will surely fail. Abandoning what is easy and sure to succeed to engage in what is difficult and sure to fail—this is the result of foolish delusion.

The *Zuan Yi* states: The will desires greatness, yet the heart desires smallness; wisdom desires roundness, yet conduct desires squareness; abilities desire multiplicity, yet affairs desire fewness—these six are what all people cannot but strive for. A great will embraces all things; a small heart is cautious of the slightest detail. Round wisdom is unobstructed in all matters; square conduct is upright and unbending. Multifaceted ability accomplishes all; few affairs mean simplicity in what one holds. The sage’s conduct does not employ shamans or mediums, yet spirits dare not precede him—unified through sincerity alone.

The *Zuan Yi* states: A state’s harsh policies erupt like the great floods of rivers, like the sudden storms of wind and rain—yet they do not last long. Ruin comes swiftly. Only those who worry over lacking virtue and know how to change can turn misfortune into fortune, weakness into strength. That one must not be self-satisfied is clear.

chunks.original_text: 老子曰福之起也绵绵祸之生也纷纷祸福之数微而不可见圣人见其始终故不可不察明主之赏罚非以为己以为国也适于己而无功于国者不施赏焉逆于己而便于国者不加罚焉故义载乎宜谓之君子遗义之宜谓之小人通智得而不劳其次劳而不病其下病而益劳【按明刋本益作亦误】古之人味而不舍也今之人舍而不味也纣为象箸而箕子啼【按明刋本啼作唏】鲁以偶人葬而孔子叹见其所始即知其所终 缵义祸福之机有开必先可不察欤赏罚人主之大柄非以为己以为国也君子小人有义利之间治而不劳政之上也劳而不病政之次也病而益劳政斯下矣夫箕子之泣象箸孔子之叹偶人国有不待终而知其亡 老子曰仁者人之所慕也义者人之所高也为人所慕为人所高或身死国亡者不周于时也故知仁义而不知世权者不达于道也五帝贵德三王用义五伯任力今取帝王之道施五伯之世非其道也故善否同非誉在俗趋行等逆顺在时知天之所为知人之所行即有以经于世矣知天而不知人即无以与俗交知人而不知天即无以与道防直志适情即坚强贼之以身役物即阴阳食之 缵义道之不行也我知之矣时异故也五帝贵德三王用义五伯任力当五伯之世而施帝王之道者不知于时也不知时则是不知天不知人矣何以经于世哉 得道之人外化而内不化外化所以知人也内不化所以全身也故内有一定之操而外能屈伸与物推移万举而不陷所贵乎道者贵其龙变也守一节推一行虽以成满犹不易拘于小好而塞于大道道者寂寞以虚无非有为于物也不以有为于己也是故举事而顺道者非道者之所为道之所施也 缵义龙虎变化大人之道也得道之人与物推移而不陷是故老子有犹龙之称夫体道虚无外不有于物内不有于己道无不施天下化矣 天地之所覆载日月之所照明阴阳之所煦雨露之所润道德之所扶皆同一和是故能戴大圆者履大方镜太清者视大明立太平者处大堂能防于防防者与日月同光无形而生于有形是故真人托期于灵台而归居于物之初视于防防听于无声防防之中独有晓焉寂寞之中独有照焉其用之乃不用不用而后能用之也其知之乃不知不知而后能知之也 缵义和也者天下之达道也天之覆地之载同乎一和而已王者戴圆履方处大堂而立太平者和其可失乎真人归居于物之初必有独见于防防之中是故用有不用而后能用知有不知而后能知夫是之谓大和 道者物之所道也德者生之所扶也仁者积恩之证也义者比于心而合于众适者也道灭而德兴德衰而仁义生故上世道而不德中世守德而不怀下世绳绳惟恐失仁义故君子非义无以生失义即失其所以生小人非利无以活失利则失其所以活故君子惧矢义小人惧失利观其所惧祸福异矣 缵义道德仁义裂而皇帝王伯分世变使之然也道以导之德以生之仁以恩之义以宜之四代之治固若不同而其君臣有分则一焉夫道而不德者皇德而不怀者帝恐失仁义者王义失其宜智诈兴矣 老子曰事或欲利之适足以害之或欲害之乃足以利之夫病湿而强餐之热病渴而强饮之寒此众人之所养也而良医所以为病也快于目说于心愚者之所利有道者之所避圣人者先迕而后合众人先合而后迕故祸福之门利害之反不可不察也 缵义事有欲利而害欲害而利非人力之所可必者物或使之也是故先迕而后合者圣人之道先合而后迕者众人之道祸福倚伏利害相反其不可不察也如此
chunks.translated_text:
Laozi said: Fortune arises softly, softly; misfortune arises in tangled profusion. The workings of fortune and misfortune are subtle and invisible, yet the sage perceives their beginning and end—therefore, one cannot but examine them closely. The enlightened ruler’s rewards and punishments are not for his own sake but for the sake of the state. If something pleases him yet brings no benefit to the state, he does not bestow reward; if something offends him yet benefits the state, he does not impose punishment. Thus, one whose actions are borne by what is fitting is called a noble person; one who abandons what is fitting is called a petty person. Those who attain understanding without toil rank highest; those who toil without suffering harm rank next; those who suffer harm yet toil all the more rank lowest. The ancients savored without ceasing; the people of today cease without savoring. When Zhou made ivory chopsticks, Jizi wept; when Lu buried with wooden figurines, Confucius sighed. Seeing the beginning, one knows the end.

The *Zuan Yi* states: The mechanism of fortune and misfortune has an opening—must one not examine it? Reward and punishment are the ruler’s great handles, not for his own sake but for the sake of the state. Between the noble person and the petty person lies the distinction of righteousness and profit. Governing without toil is the highest form of governance; toiling without suffering harm is the next; suffering harm yet toiling all the more is the lowest. When Jizi wept over ivory chopsticks and Confucius sighed over wooden figurines, the fate of the state could be known without awaiting its end.

Laozi said: Benevolence is what people admire; righteousness is what people esteem. To be admired and esteemed by others, yet to perish oneself or lose one’s state—this is due to being out of step with the times. Thus, one who knows benevolence and righteousness but does not know the balance of the world does not attain the Dao. The Five Emperors valued virtue; the Three Kings employed righteousness; the Five Hegemons relied on force. To apply the Dao of emperors and kings in the age of the Five Hegemons is not the Dao. Therefore, good and bad coincide; praise and blame lie in custom; conduct is equal; compliance and opposition lie in the times. Knowing Heaven’s actions and understanding human conduct—only then can one manage the world. Knowing Heaven but not people, one has no means to engage with custom; knowing people but not Heaven, one has no means to guard the Dao. A steadfast will and compliant nature—these are firm and strong, yet they are harmed by the self and enslaved by things, consumed by yin and yang.

The *Zuan Yi* states: The Dao does not prevail—I know why: the times have changed. The Five Emperors valued virtue; the Three Kings employed righteousness; the Five Hegemons relied on force. To apply the Dao of emperors and kings in the age of the Five Hegemons is to be ignorant of the times. Ignorant of the times, one is ignorant of Heaven and people—how can one manage the world? The person who attains the Dao adapts outwardly yet remains unchanged inwardly. Outward adaptation is how one knows others; inner constancy is how one preserves the self. Thus, inwardly possessing a steadfast principle while outwardly bending and stretching, moving with things—no action leads to entrapment. What is prized in the Dao is its dragon-like transformation. Clinging to a single node, advancing a single conduct, though one may achieve fulfillment, is still not as good as being unbound by petty preferences and unobstructed by the great Dao. The Dao is quiescent and empty, not acting upon things, nor acting upon itself. Therefore, in acting in accord with the Dao, it is not the Dao that acts—it is the Dao’s application.

The *Zuan Yi* states: The dragon and tiger transform—this is the Dao of the great person. The person who attains the Dao moves with things yet does not fall into entrapment. Thus, Laozi was called "like a dragon." Embracing the Dao, empty and formless, outwardly not possessing things, inwardly not possessing the self—the Dao is applied without exception, and the world is transformed.

What Heaven covers and Earth bears, what the sun and moon illuminate, what yin and yang warm, what rain and dew moisten, what the Dao and virtue support—all share a single harmony. Thus, one who can bear the great circle walks the great square; one who mirrors the great clarity sees the great brightness; one who establishes great peace dwells in the great hall. One who guards what is to be guarded shines like the sun and moon. Without form, it is born from form. Thus, the true person entrusts their destiny to the numinous terrace and returns to dwell in the origin of things. Seeing what is to be guarded, hearing the soundless—within what is to be guarded, there is unique understanding; within quiescence, there is unique illumination. Its use is non-use; only through non-use can it be used. Its knowledge is non-knowledge; only through non-knowledge can it be known.

The *Zuan Yi* states: Harmony is the universal Dao of the world. Heaven’s covering and Earth’s bearing share a single harmony—how can the ruler who wears the circle, walks the square, dwells in the great hall, and establishes great peace lose it? The true person returns to dwell in the origin of things and must have unique insight within what is to be guarded. Thus, use arises from non-use, and only then can it be used; knowledge arises from non-knowledge, and only then can it be known. This is called the great harmony.

The Dao is what things follow; virtue is what life relies upon; benevolence is the proof of accumulated kindness; righteousness is what aligns with the heart and accords with the multitude. When the Dao declines, virtue arises; when virtue wanes, benevolence and righteousness emerge. Thus, the highest age followed the Dao without virtue; the middle age upheld virtue without cherishing it; the later age clung tightly, fearing the loss of benevolence and righteousness. Therefore, the noble person cannot live without righteousness; losing righteousness, one loses what sustains life. The petty person cannot survive without profit; losing profit, one loses what sustains existence. Thus, the noble person fears losing righteousness; the petty person fears losing profit. Observing what they fear, fortune and misfortune diverge.

The *Zuan Yi* states: Dao, virtue, benevolence, and righteousness split, and the Yellow Emperor, emperors, kings, and hegemons divided the ages—changes in the world made it so. The Dao guides; virtue gives life; benevolence bestows kindness; righteousness makes fitting. The governance of the four ages may differ, yet the distinction between ruler and minister remains the same. Those who follow the Dao without virtue are sovereigns; those who possess virtue without cherishing it are emperors; those who fear losing benevolence and righteousness are kings; when righteousness loses its fittingness, cunning and deceit arise.

Laozi said: Some matters, when one desires to benefit them, only end in harm; others, when one desires to harm them, end in benefit. Those with dampness ailments who force themselves to eat, those with heat ailments who force themselves to drink cold—these are what the multitude nurtures, yet what the good physician treats as illness. Pleasing to the eye, delightful to the heart—these are what the foolish consider beneficial, yet what the person of the Dao avoids. The sage first opposes and later aligns; the multitude first aligns and later opposes. Thus, the gate of fortune and misfortune, the reversal of benefit and harm—these cannot but be examined.

The *Zuan Yi* states: Some matters, when one desires to benefit them, end in harm; others, when one desires to harm them, end in benefit—not by human effort can this be determined, for things may cause it. Thus, first opposing and later aligning is the Dao of the sage; first aligning and later opposing is the way of the multitude. Fortune and misfortune intertwine; benefit and harm reverse—how can one not examine them?

chunks.original_text: 老子曰有功离仁义者即见疑有罪有仁义者必见信故仁义者事之常顺也天下之尊爵也虽谋得计当虑患解图国必存其事有离仁义者其功必不遂也言虽无中于防其计无益于国而心周于君合于仁义者身必存故曰百言百计常不当者不若舍趋而审仁义也 缵义仁义者道之孙德之子欤四者若不相及而未尝相离故仁义天下之尊爵也贵以身为天下者可不舍趋而审诸仁义乎 老子曰教本乎君子小人被其泽利本乎小人君子享其功使君子小人各得其宜即通功易事而道达矣人多欲即伤义多忧即害智故治国乐所以存虐国乐所以亡水下流而广大君下臣而聪明君不与臣争而治道通故君根本也臣枝叶也根本不美而枝叶茂者未之有也 缵义君子小人均是人也为君子而教不被于小人何德以资小人之养哉治国乐其存虐国乐其亡君善下而不争则群臣献其忠柢固根深而国安矣 老子曰慈父之爱子者非求其报不可内解于心圣主之养民非为己用也性不能已也及恃其力赖其功勋而必穷有以为即恩不接矣故用众人之所爱即得众人之力举众人之所喜即得众人之心故见其所始即知其所终 缵义父子之心天性也父之爱子君之养民一有望报之心恩其失矣是故因其利而利之则得众人之力推其善而善之则得众人之心子其有不孝臣其有不忠乎 老子曰人以义爱党以群强是故德之所施者博即威之所行者远义之所加者薄即武之所制者小 缵义君以天下为心人以义爱则忠孝乃兴党以群强则奸雄遂起安危所系可不察而辩之 老子曰以不义而得之又不布施患及其身不能为人又无以自为可谓愚人无以异于枭爱其子也故持而盈之不如其已揣而锐之不可长保德之中有道道之中有德其化不可极阳中有阴阴中有阳万事尽然不可胜明福至祥存祸至祥先见祥而不为善即福不来见不祥而行善即祸不至利与害同门祸与福同邻非神圣莫之能分故曰祸兮福所倚福兮祸所伏孰知其极 缵义祸福倚伏如影随形货倍而入必倍而出善积而不善用如畜枭为子寡不自害利害之机反兮覆兮非神圣莫之能知 人之将疾也必先甘鱼之味国之将亡也必先恶忠臣之语故疾之将死者不可为良医国之将亡者不可为忠谋修之身然后可以治民居家理然后可移于官长故曰修之身其德乃真修之家其德乃余修之国其德乃丰民之所以生活衣与食也事周于衣食则有功不周于衣食则无功事无功德不长故随时而不成无更其刑顺时而不成无更其理时将复起是谓道纪缵义国非民不立民非食不生不易之理也是故民足于衣食则可活不足于衣食则防功功不立则德不长矣 帝王富其民霸王富其地危国富其吏治国若不足亡国囷仓虚故曰上无事而民自富上无为而民自化起师十万日费千金师旅之后必有凶年故兵者不祥之器也非君子之宝也和大怨必有余怨奈何其为不善也古者亲近不以言说来远不以言使近者悦远者来与民同欲即和与民同守即固与民同念者知得民力者富得民誉者显行有召冦言有致祸无先人言后人而已附耳之语流闻千里言者祸也舌者机也出言不当驷马不追 缵义无古今治乱而不易者土宇也古之今之或治或乱而不一者君民也帝王富其民霸王富其地危国富其吏治国若不足亡国囷仓虚是故唐虞之代天下富战国之世无富民 昔者中黄子曰天有五方地有五行声有五音物有五味色有五章人有五位故天地之间有二十五人也
chunks.translated_text:
Laozi said: Those who achieve merit yet depart from benevolence and righteousness will be met with suspicion; those who commit faults yet possess benevolence and righteousness will surely be trusted. Thus, benevolence and righteousness are the constant compliance of affairs, the exalted rank of the world. Even if plans are obtained and calculations prove fitting, one must still consider calamities and resolve schemes; for the state to endure, its affairs must be preserved. Those who depart from benevolence and righteousness—though their merit may seem complete—will not ultimately succeed. Though their words may not breach defenses and their plans bring no benefit to the state, if their hearts are devoted to the ruler and align with benevolence and righteousness, their persons will surely be preserved. Thus it is said: A hundred words, a hundred plans—if none ever prove fitting, it is better to abandon haste and carefully examine benevolence and righteousness.

The *Zuan Yi* states: Benevolence and righteousness—are they not the grandchildren of the Dao and the children of virtue? Though these four may seem unrelated, they have never been separate. Thus, benevolence and righteousness are the exalted rank of the world. For one who values governing the world with their person, how can they not abandon haste and carefully examine these—benevolence and righteousness?

Laozi said: Teaching originates with the noble person, yet the petty person receives its benefit; profit originates with the petty person, yet the noble person enjoys its fruits. When noble and petty persons each attain their proper place, their functions interchange and affairs proceed smoothly. When desires multiply, righteousness is harmed; when anxieties multiply, wisdom is impaired. Thus, in governing a state, joy preserves it; in a tyrannical state, joy destroys it. Water flows downward and becomes vast; the ruler lowers himself before his ministers and gains clarity. When the ruler does not contend with his ministers, the Dao of governance flows freely. Thus, the ruler is the root, the ministers the branches. Never has there been a case where the root is unsound yet the branches flourish.

The *Zuan Yi* states: Noble and petty persons are equally human. If one is noble yet their teaching does not extend to the petty, what virtue can provide for the petty’s sustenance? When a state is well-governed, joy preserves it; when a state is tyrannical, joy destroys it. When the ruler excels in humility and does not contend, ministers offer their loyalty. When the root is firm and deep, the state is secure.

Laozi said: The compassionate father’s love for his child does not seek repayment; it cannot be dissolved within the heart. The sagely ruler’s nurturing of the people is not for personal use—it is a nature that cannot be restrained. Yet if one relies on their strength, depends on their merit, and inevitably exhausts it, once there is something to be gained, kindness no longer reaches them. Thus, employing what the multitude loves, one gains the multitude’s strength; raising what the multitude delights in, one gains the multitude’s hearts. Therefore, seeing their beginning, one knows their end.

The *Zuan Yi* states: The bond between father and child is a heavenly nature. The father’s love for his child and the ruler’s nurturing of the people—if either harbors an expectation of repayment, kindness is lost. Thus, benefiting others through what benefits them, one gains the multitude’s strength; promoting goodness through what is good, one gains the multitude’s hearts. How could children then be disobedient, or ministers disloyal?

Laozi said: People unite through righteousness and grow strong through fellowship. Thus, where virtue is bestowed widely, its authority extends far; where righteousness is applied thinly, military control is limited.

The *Zuan Yi* states: When the ruler takes the world as his heart and people unite through righteousness, loyalty and filial piety flourish; when factions grow strong through fellowship, treacherous heroes arise. The balance of safety and danger cannot but be examined and discerned.

Laozi said: One who obtains through unrighteousness and does not distribute, bringing calamity upon themselves—unable to serve others, yet having nothing for themselves—can only be called a fool, no different from the owl that loves its young. Thus, holding and filling it is not as good as stopping; sharpening and honing it cannot be long preserved. In the center of virtue lies the Dao; in the center of the Dao lies virtue. Its transformations cannot be exhausted. Within yang lies yin; within yin lies yang. All things are thus—beyond enumeration. When fortune arrives, auspicious signs appear; when calamity approaches, auspicious signs precede it. Seeing the auspicious yet not doing good, fortune does not come; seeing the inauspicious yet practicing goodness, calamity does not arrive. Profit and harm share the same gate; misfortune and fortune dwell as neighbors. None but the divine and sagely can distinguish them. Thus it is said: Calamity—fortune leans upon it; fortune—calamity lies concealed within. Who knows their limit?

The *Zuan Yi* states: Misfortune and fortune lean upon each other like a shadow following form. Wealth doubled in entry will be doubled in exit. Accumulating goodness yet not employing it is like raising an owl as one’s child—few do not harm themselves. The mechanism of profit and harm turns back and forth—none but the divine and sagely can know it.

When a person is about to fall ill, they first crave the rich flavors of fish and meat; when a state is about to perish, it first detests the words of loyal ministers. Thus, one on the verge of death cannot be saved by a good physician; a state on the verge of collapse cannot be aided by loyal counsel. Cultivate the self, then one can govern the people; order the household, then one can advance to office. Thus it is said: Cultivate the self, and one’s virtue becomes genuine; cultivate the household, and one’s virtue overflows; cultivate the state, and one’s virtue abounds. The people’s means of living are clothing and food. When affairs are sufficient in clothing and food, merit is achieved; when insufficient, merit is absent. Without merit, virtue does not grow. Thus, following the times without success—do not alter the punishments; adapting to the times without success—do not change the principles. When the time is about to turn, this is called the thread of the Dao.

The *Zuan Yi* states: A state does not stand without its people; the people do not live without food—this is an unchanging principle. Thus, when the people have enough clothing and food, they can live; when they lack clothing and food, merit is obstructed. Without merit, virtue does not grow.

The true king enriches the people; the hegemonic king enriches the land; the endangered state enriches its officials; the well-governed state appears insufficient; the doomed state’s granaries are empty. Thus it is said: When the ruler does nothing, the people enrich themselves; when the ruler does not act, the people transform themselves. Mobilizing an army of a hundred thousand costs a thousand gold per day. After military campaigns, there are inevitably years of famine. Thus, arms are inauspicious instruments, not the treasure of the noble person. Reconciling great resentment must leave lingering resentment—how can it be used for what is not good? In ancient times, those nearby were not summoned with words, and those afar were not dispatched with words. When those nearby are pleased, those afar come. When desires are shared with the people, harmony is achieved; when defenses are shared with the people, stability is secured; when thoughts are shared with the people, wisdom is gained; when the people’s strength is obtained, wealth is secured; when the people’s praise is won, renown is achieved. Actions invite bandits; words bring calamity. There is no misfortune greater than speaking before others—merely following them. Whispered words travel a thousand miles. The speaker invites calamity; the tongue is the trigger. Once words are spoken amiss, even a team of four horses cannot retrieve them.

The *Zuan Yi* states: From ancient times to the present, what has not changed is the land; what has varied between order and chaos is the relationship between ruler and people. The true king enriches the people; the hegemonic king enriches the land; the endangered state enriches its officials; the well-governed state appears insufficient; the doomed state’s granaries are empty. Thus, in the eras of Yao and Shun, the world was prosperous; in the Warring States period, there were no wealthy people.

Formerly, Zhonghuangzi said: Heaven has five directions, earth has five phases, sound has five notes, things have five flavors, colors have five hues, and people have five positions. Thus, between heaven and earth, there are twenty-five types of people.

The highest five ranks include the divine person, the perfected person, the Dao person, the utmost person, and the sage. The next five ranks include the virtuous person, the worthy person, the wise person, the good person, and the eloquent person. The middle five ranks include the public-spirited person, the loyal person, the trustworthy person, the righteous person, and the ritual-observant person. The following five ranks include the scholar, the artisan, the forester, the farmer, and the merchant. The lowest five ranks include the common person, the servant, the foolish person, the base person, and the petty person. The difference between the highest five and the lowest five is like that between humans and oxen or horses.

The sage sees with the eyes, hears with the ears, speaks with the mouth, and walks with the feet. The perfected person, however, sees without looking, hears without listening, follows without walking, and is impartial without speaking. Thus, what the sage employs to move the world is something the perfected person has never transgressed. What the worthy person uses to correct世俗 is something the sage has never observed.

The so-called Dao has no front or back, no left or right; the myriad things are profoundly united, without "is" or "is not." The *Zuan Yi* records that Zhonghuangzi was an ancient perfected person. His words state: "Humans have five positions, each with five gradations, totaling twenty-five in all. The highest is the divine person; the lowest is the petty person. The difference between the highest five and the lowest five is like that between humans and oxen or horses—petty persons violate the Dao and defy virtue, no different from oxen or horses in robes. The sage does not match the perfected person; the worthy person does not match the sage. Only because their attainment of the Dao differs in depth do their ranks likewise follow."

chunks.original_text: 文子缵义卷八　　　　　宋　杜道坚　撰 自然篇 旧注至道鸿洞为万物母槖钥翕施无有涘崖是曰自然盖道之绝传不知而然亦非不然万物皆然不得不然然而自然非有能然无所因寄故曰自然也 老子曰清虚者天之明也无为者治之常也 旧注夫虚中有灵暗中有明孰能见之与道同也无为自治万物皆成也 去恩惠舍圣智外贤能废仁义灭事故弃佞辩禁奸伪即贤不肖者齐于道矣 旧注去此七者即贤无所尚愚无所愧鸿洞大道归复自然也 静即同虚即通至德无为万物皆容虚静之道天长地久神微周盈于物无宰 旧注心既虚矣无所不通德既充矣无所不容故能神用而无主周行而不殆焉 十二月运行周而复始 旧注谓十二月转轮无穷终而复始天之道也 金木水火土其势相害其道相待 旧注五运相推一王一衰寒暑递进退有时生杀有道不失其宜 故至寒伤物无寒不可至暑伤物无暑不可故可与不可皆可是以大道无所不可可在于其理见可不趋见不可不去可与不可相为左右相为表里 旧注寒暑代谢此天地之道也礼教刑罚圣人之法也然寒暑虽酷不可无也时顺即何伤刑罚虽惨不可废也理当即非害见可即行不可即止 凡事之要必从一始时为之纪自古及今未尝变易谓之天理 旧注一者道之子君之柄古今虽异动用未殊如轴运毂以内制外轮转无穷与天始终 上执大明下用其光道生万物理于阴阳化为四时分为五行各得其所与时徃来法度有常下及无能上道不倾群臣一意天地之道无为而备无求而得是以知其无为而有益也 旧注天垂象以明照四方君立法以临制天下蛰虫昭苏黎庶防惠阴阳不差万物有常自非无为不能有益于国昔尧治天下而修身也 老子曰朴至大者无形状道至大者无度量故天圆不中规地方不中矩徃古来今谓之宙四方上下谓之宇道在其中而莫知其所故其见不远者不可与言大其知不博者不可与论至夫禀道与物通者无以相非旧注道德至大无形状天地至广无度量近在毫发之间而莫见远则宇宙之内而难测自非博达通物者莫能明至道之原是非之境也 故三皇五帝法籍殊方其得民心一也 旧注制法虽殊敬民一也
chunks.translated_text:
**Wenzi Zuan Yi, Scroll Eight**
*Compiled by Du Daojian of the Song*
**The Spontaneous**

The ancient commentaries state: The supreme Dao is vast and boundless, the mother of the myriad things, the bellows and key that open and close without limit or boundary—this is called the Spontaneous. For the Dao’s transmission is utterly cut off: things are so without knowing why, yet it is not that they are not so. All things are thus, cannot but be thus. Yet the Spontaneous is not something that can make them so; it has no cause or dependence. Hence it is called the Spontaneous.

Laozi said: “Purity and emptiness are Heaven’s clarity; non-action is governance’s constancy.”
The old commentary: Within emptiness there is spirit; within darkness there is light. Who can perceive it? It is one with the Dao. Through non-action, one governs the self, and the myriad things all attain completion.

Abandon kindness and favor, set aside sageliness and wisdom, cast out worthiness and ability, discard benevolence and righteousness, extinguish affairs and events, reject flattery and sophistry, forbid deceit and falsehood—then the worthy and the unworthy are equalized in the Dao.
The old commentary: Remove these seven, and the worthy have nothing to esteem, the foolish nothing to shame themselves over. The vast Dao returns to the Spontaneous.

Stillness is identical to emptiness; in emptiness, there is penetration. Supreme virtue is non-action, and the myriad things all find accommodation. The Dao of emptiness and stillness is as enduring as Heaven and Earth. Its spirit is subtle, pervading all things without dominion.
The old commentary: When the mind is empty, nothing is impenetrable; when virtue is full, nothing is excluded. Thus it functions spiritually without a master, circulating without end.

The twelve months revolve in cycles, returning to their beginning.
The old commentary: The twelve months turn without cease, ending and beginning anew—such is Heaven’s Dao.

Metal, wood, water, fire, and earth: their forces harm one another, yet their Dao depends on one another.
The old commentary: The five phases advance in succession, one flourishing while another declines. Cold and heat alternate in due measure; advance and retreat occur in season. Generation and destruction follow the Dao, never losing their proper order.

Thus extreme cold harms things, yet without cold it cannot be; extreme heat harms things, yet without heat it cannot be. Therefore, what can be and what cannot be are both acceptable. The great Dao has nothing it cannot accept; its acceptance lies in principle. When what is acceptable is seen, do not hasten; when what is unacceptable is seen, do not withdraw. The acceptable and the unacceptable serve as each other’s left and right, as each other’s inner and outer.
The old commentary: Cold and heat succeed one another—this is the Dao of Heaven and Earth. Ritual and punishment are the laws of the sage. Though cold and heat may be harsh, they cannot be absent; when the time is right, what harm is there? Though punishments may be severe, they cannot be abolished; when principle demands it, they are not harmful. When what is acceptable is seen, act; when what is unacceptable is seen, desist.

The essentials of all affairs must begin with unity; when the time is taken as their standard, from antiquity to the present they have never changed. This is called Heavenly principle.
The old commentary: Unity is the child of the Dao, the handle of the ruler. Though antiquity and the present differ, their functioning remains unchanged—like an axle turning a hub, controlling what is within while the wheel revolves endlessly, beginning and ending with Heaven.

Above, it grasps the great brightness; below, it employs its light. The Dao generates the myriad things, ordering them through yin and yang, transforming them into the four seasons, dividing them into the five phases. Each attains its place, coming and going with the seasons, following constant standards. Extending even to the incapable, the Dao above does not falter. All ministers are of one mind; the Dao of Heaven and Earth is non-action yet complete, without seeking yet attaining. Thus we know that non-action is beneficial.
The old commentary: Heaven hangs its images to illuminate the four directions; the ruler establishes laws to govern all under Heaven. Hibernating creatures awaken; the common people are protected. Yin and yang do not err; the myriad things have constancy. Without non-action, one cannot benefit the state. In ancient times, Yao governed all under Heaven by cultivating himself.

Laozi said: “The greatest simplicity has no form; the greatest Dao has no measure.” Thus Heaven is round yet does not conform to the compass; Earth is square yet does not conform to the carpenter’s square. From past to present is called *zhou*; the four directions and above and below are called *yu*. The Dao is within them, yet none know its place. Therefore, those whose vision is not far-reaching cannot be spoken to of greatness; those whose knowledge is not broad cannot be discoursed with on the supreme. Those who receive the Dao and communicate with things have nothing by which to oppose one another.
The old commentary: The Dao is utterly great, without form; Heaven and Earth are utterly vast, without measure. It is near, in the space between a hair’s breadth, yet unseen; it is far, within the cosmos, yet unfathomable. Without broad understanding and communication with things, none can comprehend the source of the supreme Dao or the realm of right and wrong.

Thus the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors had different laws and methods, yet their attainment of the people’s hearts was one.
The old commentary: Though their systems of law differed, their reverence for the people was the same.

chunks.original_text: 若夫规矩勾绳巧之具也而非所以为巧也故无虽师文不能成其曲徒即不能独悲故悲之具也非所以为悲也 旧注夫万物虽曰自然皆有回假不能独运其犹勾绳者巧之制也而非巧也妙在于人无防即不宜器者悲之具也而非悲也无则不悲也 至于神和游于心手之间放意写神论变而形于者父不能以教子子亦不能受之于父此不传之道也旧注师文弹琴注指钩写神放意游心手之间和阴阳之候遂使变律四时气感万物至于父子虽亲不能传者妙之极矣此亦道不可传受也 故肃者形之君也而寂寞者音之主也 旧注肃静也故静中生形以静为君寂中有音以寞为主 老子曰天地之道以德为主道为之命物以自正至防甚内不以事贵故不待功而立不以位为尊不待名而显不须礼而庄不用兵而强 旧注道生为命德畜为主人能调防神气正性命内保精防外弃烦累何须名位而自尊不待兵甲而人不非也 故道立而不教明照而不察道立而不教者不夺人能也明照而不察者不害其事也 旧注道存则教遗明极则无察然后能任所冒事无有害 夫教道者逆于德害于物故阴阳四时金木水火土同道而异理万物同情而异形知者不相教能者不相受故圣人立法以道民之心各使自然故生者无德也死者无怨也【案明刋本此二句无二也字】 旧注夫逆德者谓德衰而教兴容物者谓先损而后益且五行异性万物殊形由教有本末人有贤愚圣人垂法制教开导愚使智者相授能者不隐各尽其分归乎自然生不矜其德死不怨乎天 天地不仁以万物为刍狗圣人不仁以百姓为刍狗旧注天地生万物圣人养百姓岂有心于物有私于人哉一以观之有同刍狗 夫慈爱仁义者近狭之道也狭者入大而迷近者行远而惑圣人之道入大不迷行远不惑常虚自守可以为极是谓天德 旧注道德微仁义近狭中庸登小径以致迷上圣陟通衢而无滞自非灵府恒明安能与天为极 老子曰圣人天覆地载日月照临阴阳四时化懐万物而不同无故无新无踈无亲 旧注此圣人之德也覆载若天地照临如日月转轮如四时殊俗异草木昆虫莫不安其居遂其性岂有新故亲踈于其间者哉 故能法天者天不一时地不一财人不一事故绪业多端趋行多方 旧注言天以一时则不能成岁地以一财则用之有极人有一能未足为贵也 故用兵者或轻或重或贪或廉四者相反不可一也旧注各趋所利故不一 轻者欲发重者欲止贪者欲取廉者不利非其有也旧注夫兵众者心欲一今重者欲止轻者欲发各趋其便是不一也不一则遇敌而败但量其才力均轻重而使之则无徃不克 故勇者可令进斗不可令持坚重者可令固守不可令陵敌贪者可令攻取不可令分财廉者可令守分不可令进取信者可令持约不可令应变五者圣人兼用而材使之 旧注惟圣人善用其能不失其所能故天下无敌也 夫天地不懐一物阴阳不产一故海不让水潦以成其大山林不让枉桡以成其崇峦圣人不辞负薪之言以广其名夫守一隅而遗万方取一物而弃其余即所得者寡而所治者浅矣 旧注夫道不广不能懐万物圣人德不厚无以纳防言故一能不敢恃一隅不可守守之者细恃之者浅也 老子曰天之所覆地之所载日月之所照形殊性异各有安乐乐其所为乐者乃所以为悲也安其所为安者乃所以为危也 旧注以已乐乐之则悲因其乐乐之即乐以已安安之则危因其生而安之则安也 故圣人之牧民也使各便其性安其居处其宜为其所能周其所适施其所宜如此则万物一齐无由相过旧注圣人牧民使异性殊形各适其宜虽则万有若一体不能相越故曰一齐
